content:
Posted: October 24, 2014
												I am just going to throw in my 2 cents.I played this game before and was pretty hardcore about it back in that time. Tried multi-box farming and other "non-normal" way to make money before the patch that removes energy requirement on elevator. So you know I am not those casual players with less than 20 hours game time who will be shouting "omg this game is so fun so cute, play it and you will never regret".The gameplay was fun, but grind wall hits me hard after about 20 hours of gameplay--just like almost every other free-to-play game out there.For example, in order to do higher level content, you can:1. play this game everyday for an hour for 2 weeks so that you accumulates enough mats which could upgrade your gears2. forget about life, forget about work, grind countinously and get those gears in a single day3. swipe your card and purchase gears directly from the in-game auction houseI quited playing seriously simply because the game was not rewarding enough based on the time I invested in this game. But I still log back in once in awhile just to listen to the music and slash some enemies.Recent patches are always cash-oriented, which, for sure, increase the grind level of this game in general.In conclusion, Spiral Knights is a medicore F2P game. Gameplay is interesting and unique, but it requires serious grinding to get anything you want. I would recommend playing it casually--explore the world, try out new things, and log off. If you want to play this game hardcore, it will be very repetitive, frustrating, and time-consuming.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 11, 2015
												UPDATE: Three Rings Design went under (quite the shocker, I know) and had the game transferred to Grey Havens, a team of ex-OOO employees who took over with no limitations from Sega on what they could and couldn't do. Sounds like the game will actually recieve content updates, right? Well, at first it kind of did, a few steps in the right direction, a bit of polishing and bug fixes, simple stuff. But just when the playerbase was starting to regain their faith in the game, the dreaded box promos returned, and returned again. The game went from a possible state of ressurrection to right back down the same exact ♥♥♥♥ing pattern of "updates" that players are sick to death of.Having played this game for over 3,000 hours on Steam alone (about another 50 or so before the Steam release) I can say this game is nothing like it used to be. It's basically a MMO dungeon crawler inspired off of The Legend of Zelda and to be quite honest it has some serious potential, and still does.Unfortunately the developing company (Three Rings Design or "OOO" for short) was bought out by Sega at one point and since then, the game started to decline. This decline quickly turned from bad to worse once its lead developer, Nick Popovich, resigned from OOO to pursue a living as an indie game developer. Before his resignation he had announced some major changes to the game that would be very welcoming to players both new and old and this was about 2 years ago. To this day, only a small fraction of these changes have been implemented into the game and production of new content has virtually ceased.Any updates that come to the game come in the form of prize boxes, only purchasable with real cash and contain accessories and costume pieces that provide no benefit whatsoever other than "Wowie I got the same helmet I already have 38 others of but now in a slightly different shade of red." Every time a "new" prize box is released which at this point is almost every 2 weeks, it's nothing more than a simple change of colors for the exact same items. And the cherry on top of this whole ordeal is in the off-chance that these boxes contain an item never before seen with unique stats (such as a shield or a weapon) they have insanely low drop rates and pretty much force you to spend hundreds of dollars on boxes for a small chance at it or purchasing it from another player who will more than likely have a price tag on it large enough to make you cringe.Personally, I find the game's PvP community to be the most toxic I have ever seen, comparable to League of Legends. This is just my experience, though. The game's PvP system is a whole other wall of text I could spend days writing about.Other than those points, I still find the game quite enjoyable to play when I have some friends to play with, and I also livestream it on Youtube every now and then which brings some of what's left of the game's good part of the community together for a good time, which is my goal. With friends to play with, the game is still pretty decent if you can get past its broken crafting system. Most veterans that have been around this game since its beta days would really hate to see it get shut down, but with the dev team leaving everyone in the dark and not saying anything about what they intend to do in the long run, it has left most of us to believe that the game's days are numbered.TL;DR Do I recommend the game? Yes only if you have friends to play with or want to try something new. As far as sticking around and playing actively, don't even bother unless things pick up with the people in charge behind the game and its development shows signs of well... actually being developed. But in its current state, the game's future does not look too bright so if you're looking for a new MMO to get into, steer clear of Spiral Knights (for now)

content:
Posted: February 2, 2015
												While the game is old, with updates over the past year the game has become much more free-to-play friendly than it use to be. Elevators are now free and there is no longer a Mist bar, meaning endless dungeon crawling for everyone. Leveling weapons is different, now requiring a specific item depending on the * of weapon. While hard to find at times, it is still possible to find the required item in Prize Boxes in through the dungeon. The newer updates the game have put the focus back on exploration and spending time in the Clockworks and learning the game at your own pace, not buying everything with real world money and just spending time in pvp. I have sunk easily 1000+ hours over the course of my time playing Spiral Knights and it will always be one of my most favorite games ever because of all of the memories I have made through the 3 years I have been playing.

content:
Posted: December 9, 2013
												Spiral Knights is a great game. Great story mode and I adore the graphics. Not many games have 3D cartoon-ish graphics to them, but there is one problem. . . Spiral Knights is dying and I don't want this game to die. My cousins told me that once you finish the story mode there is nothing else to do. So what I suggest is that you should expand the story mode and add new items. Back in  2012 Spiral Knights was popular, but now the population has decreased to 500-300 players. I'm begging the developers to please expand the story mode. Make an update that adds an more to the story mode. I really want to experience that feeling again when my cousins would call over Skype and we'd all play Spiral Knights, but because we finished the story there was no point in playing Spiral Knights anymore. Please expand the story mode and maybe add new items to the game. It's a big thing that I'm asking for, but there are many games out there that expand their story and keeping it fresh. The community is dying and I don't want this game to die yet. Please expand the story and add new items to the game. Keep things fresh and new.

content:
Posted: December 3, 2014
												Oh how far we've fallen... I've been playing this since 2010 and while there have been massive improvements, there have been massive failures.  Every update ends up requiring multiple shutdowns and restarts, latency has gone from annoying to game runing in several places, and once you've done everything once there really isn't anything more.  There have been no new levels, monsters, bosses, or anything for almost 2 years.  When this was new it was absolutely amazing and for new players it will be very fun.  But for those who have been around for a while it just doesn't do it anymore.  New weapons are great but if you're shooting at the same monsters over and over again in the same levels, it gets pretty boring after a while.  To be sure, you'll get hundreds of hours out of it, especially if you minimally pay and do it through old fashioned work.  But don't expect to stick around for years at near the same level of excitement.

content:
Posted: December 19, 2011
												Never, EVER go near this game. IT has caused me an unbeleavable ammount of pain. STAY AWAY!!!!It is very much pay2win oriented, since resurrecting in the dungeons uses up energy and you only get roughly 100 per day (and each time you revive, it's cost doubles, so first it's 10, then 20 then 40, etc.).It is absolutely imperative that you live a maximum of 7 feet away from their servers, otherwise you'll have to predict enemy movement before they even telegraph it. Same goes for your own actions as you'll see your own sword pass through enemies unless you time it juuuuust right.If you DO decide to play this, remember: your shield is TOOL to be used often. Use it's pushing ability to scatter surrounding enemies away before they strike (again, have to time it right or you'll get hit despite having your shield up).Not recommended.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 27, 2012
												Ah, Spiral Knights. How can I keep this recommendation within the character limit. Well, it's a free-to-play action-based MMO, but it remains free-to-play due to a mechanic that allows only so much playtime each day. And if you get addicted, which you will, you need to at least buy a monthly pass, that's basically required to enjoy the game anyway, unless you only have an hour or two to play each day anyway, in which case this is a perfect system for you. The game starts out easy, the controls are very simple, and they recently added an optional tutorial/questing system, which makes it even easier to start playing. However, things get insanely challenging later on. Bullet hells, spike hells, fiery helly hells. There are even special areas made just to be cruel hells. Admittedly it gets easier once you become experienced and know what to expect, but there are still areas that are basically impossible to progress through solo. This game will teach you how to use a shield, I'll say that.UPDATE:I'm changing this recommendation from positive to negative. This game is dying. A year ago, this was an underappreciated gem of an MMO. There was new content being regularly released for free that drew you in, and then while you were here there were cosmetics and boosts that you could pay for if you wanted to. This is how the free-to-play model should work, content that draws you in and keeps you playing while simultaneously not being locked behind a paywall and being open to anyone, whether they pay or not. And for the most part, this model still applies to new players who haven't experienced all the content yet.But the new content updates that comprise the backbone of this model have long since died off. Promises were made and never kept, the lead developer upped and left, and a noticeably large chunk of the playerbase has died off due to boredom. It feels like a lot of drive and inspiration has been lost and Three Rings thinks it can fill this void with shiny "new" reskins and repeating event content and hope that no one notices while they try to piece everything back together behind the scenes, IF they're trying to piece everything back together behind the scenes, maybe they aren't. It's been over a year now and there are STILL a bunch of unfixed problems and bugs related to the sprites update that was released just before everything fell apart.Examples: Some minerals have no purpose and get stuck in your inventory; sprites have a level numbering system that makes no sense, the "true" max level is some number over 100 that the game doesn't tell you; the only way of knowing that you've reached this "true" max level is that your sprite glitches out and stops accepting levelup food; and there are quite a few balance issues with pet abilties and ultimates, some are even outright bugs themselves.(Seraphynx's Violent Heart Attack ultimate causes targets enchanted with Heart Attack to explode. Sounds cool, right? It does until you realize that the explosion does almost zero damage even in tier three and is really only good for breaking blocks. And the alternative ultimate, Iron Heart Attack, has a chance to drop defense orbs that maybe cushion half a pip's worth of damage, also in tier three. Take your pick between useless and more useless. In fact, just stay away from Seraphynx in general, its first ability has a deceptively large hitbox combined with a maximum hit limit per enemy that makes no sense, its second ability is very unreliable and might not even have an effect at all, and its third ability has too small of a radius to be useful in the team setting that it's meant to be useful in and has only enough health for one, maaaaaaybe two hits for everyone and not per person, it's mostly just for running over traps that you're too impatient to wait for. Hell, the other non-defense-oriented sprites have BETTER individual defensive abilities than the defense-oriented sprite, because the defense sprite is meant for providing defense for the whole team, yet the balance just isn't there to actually provide reliable and worthwhile defensive abilities for multiple people simultaneously, it's better if everyone just brought their own Flame Barrier and Shadow Cloak buffs and went from there. Unless you just like shiny cosmetic kittens, of course.)Phew.My point is, these things are acceptable for a month or two after a big update, not a year, and the fact that so little has changed to make the game better in that time tells me that they've probably stopped caring about Spiral Knights altogether. If you're new to the game you will have all sorts of fun in everything that's been established already, but don't invest too much into your future here, at the rate things are going you won't have much of one.

content:
Posted: October 11, 2011
												Spiral Knights is your average MMORPG made 95% less cramped; instead of infinite players going through the same dungeon, there are only 4 at most per party.While the game could get a handful more people by being updated with new content on a more regular basis, at its Core it's a fun and stylish game about cyborgs(?) whacking swords and shooting hand-sized bullets at animals, robots, demons, and all sorts of fantastical monsters as they try to find a way out of an incredibly complex and artificial planet they got stuck themselves onto (Spoiler Alert: they're still stuck on it).Also cool TF2 hat is cool.  :3All-in-all, worth the download and a place in your library.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 2, 2014
												A charming, Zelda-inspired, online RPG. Beautiful art style, great soundtrack, good progression, with fun PvE and PvP. This is a great game in my opinion, and while it might not be for everyone, it is definitely a 'must-try'.There is quite a grind mid-game, but it's just enough grind to make you WANT to spend some money, but not so bad you HAVE to spend. There are not as many end-game dungeons as there should be, but you can go back to previous missions with scaled down stats (with slighty less payout). The developer (Three Rings) constantly creates new events, with new levels, and usually new costumes armor sets. These incremental updates provide new stuff to do while you wait for the next big level update.Customization in this game is HUGE, with 'costume armor' sets, and accessories to put on your armor (though you can only afford them towards end-game). It's insane how many different armor combinations you can make. I've played over 1000 hours, and even I can't remember every one!PvP will provide hours of fun, but at times can be overrun with PvP elitists (trust me, that's no fun). The "FreeToPlay" system is set up really well, and has greatly improved in a recent update (so if you played it a while ago and hated it, try it again). Currency earned by play is called "Crowns", and currency that you pay real money for is called "Energy". At any time, Crowns can be traded for Energy via the in-game energy market (thus paying real money is completely optional). Of course Energy is more desirable, but when trading with other players, they usually don't mind if you pay in Crowns. You can buy energy to speed up your progression, but is by no means neccessary to reach end-game. I have bought Energy a few times myself, but they were mostly to buy costumes or to pimp out a costume with accessories.I think my hours spent playing this game tell how fun it is. I love this game, and I would play it at the slightest mention of a new update or event.It's free, it's fun, and truly FreeToPlay, what more do I need to say? Play it NOW...!    (and if you don't like it you are a heartless scrublord)

content:
Posted: November 25, 2012
Yeah ok, first things first. It's not dead. It's a small but alive population so don't go around saying it's a dead game.Now that's out of the way, I just want to say: It's a really good game but it's corrupted with the whole P2W aspectSure there are some frusfrations like grinding and the overly done crafting system but the gameplay, atmosphere and visual is just so appealing. The crafting system is kinda annoying what with you having to go to dungeons over and over and over so you can get that one material you know need but the dungeons themselves are kinda cool and each has their own themes. Oh and when I say dungeon? I mean underground depths.You descend deeper and deeper into the earth's core as you progress through the dungeons and you will need to get better gear as things proceed but it's decently balanced. Thing is the P2W thing is just really tempting. You need that one more material? One more coin? One more whatever to do whatever it is you are doing? HERE'S SOME OFFER IN YOUR FACE JUST TO TEMPT YOU. If you resist it though, it's really irrelevant tbh. It's not like you use the P2W money to revive yourself when you are dead and if you are not skilled enough to stay alive for a long time, especially with the lag it has due to the lack of servers and maintenance, you have to restart from the beginning or anythingI love this game and I do recommend you to download and give this game a try. It's free and it's good, what's the harm really? Except the cancerous P2W system

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 12, 2014
												When I started this game, I was young and innocent. I just wanted to buy Rome-Total War(tm), to enjoy the salutations of the people. How naive I was. Spiral Knights is an eldritch land, tugging at the edges of your soul until it gets hold of a jagged piece and rends you to the core, leaving naught but a torn, gangrenous wound in its wake. Any foolhardy traveller with the intention of tasting the Elysian nectar they believe this game to be, beware. For this is no nectar, but a venus flytrap, waiting, readying its gaping, ravenous maw to snap down upon your head. Stare long into the abyss, and the abyss will stare back into you, into your soul until it is nothing but its smoldering core. With these, my dying curses, I entreat ye, do not trust this abomination. They, the fallen, all said "Its just to get another game", I said these words as well, and I find myself here, hollow, not the man I once believed I was. Overall, 7/10 it was ok I guess.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 10, 2015
												Ok so, I have played this game for so many hours even before when I had steam. When I officially got Spiral Knights for steam, I had already like 4 star armor. Honestly, this game has gone to♥♥♥♥♥♥ There are only THREE tiers! Tier 1 : A Boss Named Snarbolax Tier 2 : Jelly King / Queen and The Romolous Twins Tier 3 : Vanaduke . Now , if you want to buy gear in this game THATS A ♥♥♥♥ING PROBLEM!! Everything is SO overly priced! This game is F2P but the game ♥♥♥♥in BEGS you to use real money on it. I used to play this with my friend and it was fun, but it has gone to complete and utter♥♥♥♥♥♥! You need to keep grinding the same ♥♥♥♥ing levels for who the ♥♥♥♥ knows how many times in a day to get "rich". I will just go right out and say it, if you are not rich or you arent at least a gamer girl, You will find it SUPER hard to get ANY online friends. Sure if you are 5 star you can pickup a guy that is 1 star or a newbie as a friend, but here me out, HE/SHE WILL ♥♥♥♥ING BEG YOU FOR MONEY NON-STOP. Now if you actually get a "girlfriend / boyfriend" and they are lower star than you,  THEY WILL ♥♥♥♥ING BEG YOU TO DEATH FOR CROWNS.  Now I keep saying Stars and Crowns and let me explain. Crowns are the in-game money and Stars are like a ranking for gear in-game. SERIOUSLY I have been playing this game for 5 years min. And taken about 3 years of a break. Why? BECAUSE THE GAME IS SO ♥♥♥♥ING GRINDY ITS NOT FUNNY ANYMORE. I SWEAR, WHEN YOU GET TO TIER 3, ALL YOU WILL ♥♥♥♥ING DO, IS GRIND VANADUKE, CAUSE IT FIVES YOU ABOUT 8K + EVERY LEVEL BUT IT IS SO ♥♥♥♥ING BORING!! You try to change it up a bit a do Snarbolax or Jelly King / Queen but I promise you that you WILL go back to Vanaduke cause being rich in-game is SO important , you WILL regret it!! Basically, what I am trying to say here, you probably should not play this game if you are not willing to pay in-game money.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 11, 2015
												UPDATE: Three Rings Design went under (quite the shocker, I know) and had the game transferred to Grey Havens, a team of ex-OOO employees who took over with no limitations from Sega on what they could and couldn't do. Sounds like the game will actually recieve content updates, right? Well, at first it kind of did, a few steps in the right direction, a bit of polishing and bug fixes, simple stuff. But just when the playerbase was starting to regain their faith in the game, the dreaded box promos returned, and returned again. The game went from a possible state of ressurrection to right back down the same exact ♥♥♥♥ing pattern of "updates" that players are sick to death of.Having played this game for over 3,000 hours on Steam alone (about another 50 or so before the Steam release) I can say this game is nothing like it used to be. It's basically a MMO dungeon crawler inspired off of The Legend of Zelda and to be quite honest it has some serious potential, and still does.Unfortunately the developing company (Three Rings Design or "OOO" for short) was bought out by Sega at one point and since then, the game started to decline. This decline quickly turned from bad to worse once its lead developer, Nick Popovich, resigned from OOO to pursue a living as an indie game developer. Before his resignation he had announced some major changes to the game that would be very welcoming to players both new and old and this was about 2 years ago. To this day, only a small fraction of these changes have been implemented into the game and production of new content has virtually ceased.Any updates that come to the game come in the form of prize boxes, only purchasable with real cash and contain accessories and costume pieces that provide no benefit whatsoever other than "Wowie I got the same helmet I already have 38 others of but now in a slightly different shade of red." Every time a "new" prize box is released which at this point is almost every 2 weeks, it's nothing more than a simple change of colors for the exact same items. And the cherry on top of this whole ordeal is in the off-chance that these boxes contain an item never before seen with unique stats (such as a shield or a weapon) they have insanely low drop rates and pretty much force you to spend hundreds of dollars on boxes for a small chance at it or purchasing it from another player who will more than likely have a price tag on it large enough to make you cringe.Personally, I find the game's PvP community to be the most toxic I have ever seen, comparable to League of Legends. This is just my experience, though. The game's PvP system is a whole other wall of text I could spend days writing about.Other than those points, I still find the game quite enjoyable to play when I have some friends to play with, and I also livestream it on Youtube every now and then which brings some of what's left of the game's good part of the community together for a good time, which is my goal. With friends to play with, the game is still pretty decent if you can get past its broken crafting system. Most veterans that have been around this game since its beta days would really hate to see it get shut down, but with the dev team leaving everyone in the dark and not saying anything about what they intend to do in the long run, it has left most of us to believe that the game's days are numbered.TL;DR Do I recommend the game? Yes only if you have friends to play with or want to try something new. As far as sticking around and playing actively, don't even bother unless things pick up with the people in charge behind the game and its development shows signs of well... actually being developed. But in its current state, the game's future does not look too bright so if you're looking for a new MMO to get into, steer clear of Spiral Knights (for now)

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 18, 2014
												I'd thought the game was a bit sleazy in its restrictions through the use of Energy back before it was acquired by Sega.Now I long for the day to have the game returned to a point when it was still worth playing! As a grandfathered in player, I was what seems to amount to the new concept of "Rank 5" or so, though I'm now forced to do unchallenging missions to collect the materials necessary to level up my equipment -- which I can no longer do after they turned the "Heat" mechanic from an XP track for gear into a 60% chance of outright failure to level-up with a rare item cost.After some 20 missions blitzed through last night, I still don't have the special "rarity" items to level-up my equipment, which has been stuck at whatever level they were at back when I'd left the game before.I could buy them off the auction house, sure, but now that the entire game has been unhinged, new equipment is either unsable (my rank is too low, where before there was no such limitation that I can recall), impossible to find (as there's no real benefit to selling what you can obtain by simply grinding for the mission handouts), or impossible to afford (as with 15,000 C, I can barely afford the 2-star gear I already own).If that wasn't bad enough, nigh everything can be obtained with Energy -- the magical, in-game currency you can buy with real money.  The game will even blithely remind you as you peruse your available missions.  Want a 5th copy of this silly shovel weapon?  It's yours for the low, low price of 60 Energy!It's the most transparent attempt by Sega to exploit the playerbase of a once-passable and admittedly clever Sci-Fi BMUP dungeon-crawling RPG to milk as much money as possible.I cannot in good faith recommend a game like this.  This isn't even the "freemium" the old game used to be; it's just downright disgusting.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 3, 2014
												Oh how far we've fallen... I've been playing this since 2010 and while there have been massive improvements, there have been massive failures.  Every update ends up requiring multiple shutdowns and restarts, latency has gone from annoying to game runing in several places, and once you've done everything once there really isn't anything more.  There have been no new levels, monsters, bosses, or anything for almost 2 years.  When this was new it was absolutely amazing and for new players it will be very fun.  But for those who have been around for a while it just doesn't do it anymore.  New weapons are great but if you're shooting at the same monsters over and over again in the same levels, it gets pretty boring after a while.  To be sure, you'll get hundreds of hours out of it, especially if you minimally pay and do it through old fashioned work.  But don't expect to stick around for years at near the same level of excitement.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 13, 2015
												In regards to Spiral Knights, I feel a heavy bit of nostalgia for Phantasy Star Online for the Dreamcast from this; be it the music, art style, or overall Sega feel. It's a candy coated, charming, and light action-rpg that I get an itch for when I'm away from it for a few months. However It's a grind for gear, and there's not much in the way of customization or variety unless you play everyday in copy-cat grind-y dungeons, or shell out real money. Which, I believe, the game deserves.  The paywall feels like it hits as soon I as get in a groove, and snaps like a rubber band. I eventually come back, though, for the tight gameplay and charming design. So yah, play it.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 19, 2011
												Never, EVER go near this game. IT has caused me an unbeleavable ammount of pain. STAY AWAY!!!!It is very much pay2win oriented, since resurrecting in the dungeons uses up energy and you only get roughly 100 per day (and each time you revive, it's cost doubles, so first it's 10, then 20 then 40, etc.).It is absolutely imperative that you live a maximum of 7 feet away from their servers, otherwise you'll have to predict enemy movement before they even telegraph it. Same goes for your own actions as you'll see your own sword pass through enemies unless you time it juuuuust right.If you DO decide to play this, remember: your shield is TOOL to be used often. Use it's pushing ability to scatter surrounding enemies away before they strike (again, have to time it right or you'll get hit despite having your shield up).Not recommended.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 2, 2013
												Good game, however, the energy system is the worst free to play system I've ever seen in a game, basically you can play for free, but you can't do anything without energy which you need to buy. 100 Mist energy is the maximum energy a free to play account has which equals to five quests. Mist energy regenerates 1 energy each 13 minutes. The worst part being that if you die in a quest(instance) you need energy to revive, if you don't spend that energy, you go back to town and that 20 mist energy you paid for the quest, is now gone and you made 0 progress within the game. And if you buy crystal energy (the one that doesn't regenerate) you have only what you've paid for. I'd rather pay 50 bucks and play forever (until a DLC/expansion comes out). And don't tell me that this game is worth more than 50 bucks because it isn't. If I want to play something worth my money I would rather choose something like Guild Wars 2.Good things about this game? The co-op is very enjoyable, the ranking system is fun, the arcade system is basically an (almost) endless mode of instances and crafting could be better, a little complexity here and there won't hurt.Rating (from someone you don't know/care about) = 5/10.Hell, not enough energy to rate higher. Sorry.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 29, 2014
												I have played this game from its beta period and I previously reviewed it on April 24, 2013. Back then I stated that this was an "okay" game; worth some of your time but many of the additions made it rather annoying to play (mist energy I'm looking at you).BUT since then, I have come back to the game just recently and I have to give a pat on the back to the devs. No more wait-till-the-next-day-mobile-phone-gaming-crap. Vast improvements to the crafting of items and forging encourage you to keep playing. And the graphics are still pretty good, even today. This game has had a terrible past as oldies like me know. Having to wait for your energy to recharge and boring "NEW BOX!" patches being the only thing that was being added, as well as inflated crystal energy prices (anybody else remember them at 2000-3000 per 100?) used to make this a very "meh" experience. Though after my break of about a year from the game, it has really stepped-up and fulfilled the potential I always thought it had.6/10 8.5/10 This game really is worth the hours

When I did understand what I was supposed to do, and (rarely) why, I would enjoy the heck out of myself. The graphics are still amazing for the game, but for myself ( who doesn't like when my UI is cramped) the game got boring quick. It quickly reminded me of my first days of WoW, and how I quit after a week of trying to get used to the cramped screen. Would not reccomend for anyone who is not used to the RPG feel of a cramped screen, but if you like a cramped screen, but would enjoy a more smooth and sci-fi graphical scene, this game is for you.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 26, 2014
												This was a good game.As most other reviews mention, yes, this used to be a fun game.Now? It's plain bad. VERY bad. Think as bad as Runescape and you aren't far.(On a side note, are all MMO games programmed in Java cursed to be bad?)Sure, you may be thinking "This is an angry rant, not a review". Well, let's see...In the past, there was a thing called Mist Energy (Mist = Free, Crystal = In-Game or Real Money), up to a max of 100 at a time. If you don't play the game and didn't come across the concept in the reviews, Energy is used for the main aspects in the game. While it restricted daily playtime for free players, it encouraged cooperative gameplay, which, in turn made the community overall a nice bunch.Nowadays, you get to play as much as you want (there was a 10 Energy fee for entering levels),but everything else is slow and tedious to do. Take crafting for instance; Previously, you crafted things with Energy. It took a chunk of time, but it was pretty doable until higher levels. Today, you have to get "Crystals" to craft items.They are paid with energy or found, but are: If playing levels, as rare as a cold glass of soda in a desert If buying with in-game currency, a 3-weeks-average grindfest to craft an item If buying with real money, an "I am rich" showcase of your many 5-star itemsAnd then comes the forge system. You see, you need heat (too!) to improve your weapons, and there are up to 10 levels of heat. Previously, heat level raised automatically (ala level up when you have enough exp).Currently, heat levels are increased when you provide "Embers" to a forge. The main flaws of this system are: They suffer from the same problems of Crystals Forges are only found outside missionsTherefore, you lose many potential heat levels while searching for Embers.And now, *drumroll*...UPDATES!The updates are many, but few can be actually called updates. You may be wondering what do I mean by this. Well, most updates are cosmetics which have little to no effect on gameplay. 99.99% of those are silly recolors of 5 star items or costumes, which cost either a zillon coins or $100 of your local currency. The major updates are seldom released (the most recent having been released 4 months ago), with the majority of them being missions or equipment, with gameplay changes being perjudicial (well, only making elevators free helped players).Not to mention that none of them added to the main storyline. That's right, folks! When the main storyline is over, you have little or nothing left to do.Let's talk about the miscellania of content here: PvP and Shadow Lairs.PvP? Craft a 5 star weapon with attack speed and damage UVs (read: modifiers), suit yourself in an armor with similar modifiers (now you know why everyone runs around in wolf costumes) and you are ready to go. Enough said.Shadow Lairs? I have to admit, now that looks like something fun to do. Problem is, you need Shadow Keys to enter and a lot of Sparks of Life (used to revive) for this, both being ridiculously expensive. And, except the Shadow Key, that goes for all your fellow party members (you'll definitely want to have a full party before entering). This is the ultimate challenge in the game, but as such, it is the ultimate money sink (aside from crafting, that is).Now, if you want to play the game anyways, I won't stop you. But remember this: There are many better games out there, don't waste your time on this one unless you like seeing knights in shiny armor and impressive weapons while having a crappy semi-automatic laser pistol and that armor you managed to craft after 2 months of grinding.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 24, 2014
												I am just going to throw in my 2 cents.I played this game before and was pretty hardcore about it back in that time. Tried multi-box farming and other "non-normal" way to make money before the patch that removes energy requirement on elevator. So you know I am not those casual players with less than 20 hours game time who will be shouting "omg this game is so fun so cute, play it and you will never regret".The gameplay was fun, but grind wall hits me hard after about 20 hours of gameplay--just like almost every other free-to-play game out there.For example, in order to do higher level content, you can:1. play this game everyday for an hour for 2 weeks so that you accumulates enough mats which could upgrade your gears2. forget about life, forget about work, grind countinously and get those gears in a single day3. swipe your card and purchase gears directly from the in-game auction houseI quited playing seriously simply because the game was not rewarding enough based on the time I invested in this game. But I still log back in once in awhile just to listen to the music and slash some enemies.Recent patches are always cash-oriented, which, for sure, increase the grind level of this game in general.In conclusion, Spiral Knights is a medicore F2P game. Gameplay is interesting and unique, but it requires serious grinding to get anything you want. I would recommend playing it casually--explore the world, try out new things, and log off. If you want to play this game hardcore, it will be very repetitive, frustrating, and time-consuming.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 2, 2013
												Good game, however, the energy system is the worst free to play system I've ever seen in a game, basically you can play for free, but you can't do anything without energy which you need to buy. 100 Mist energy is the maximum energy a free to play account has which equals to five quests. Mist energy regenerates 1 energy each 13 minutes. The worst part being that if you die in a quest(instance) you need energy to revive, if you don't spend that energy, you go back to town and that 20 mist energy you paid for the quest, is now gone and you made 0 progress within the game. And if you buy crystal energy (the one that doesn't regenerate) you have only what you've paid for. I'd rather pay 50 bucks and play forever (until a DLC/expansion comes out). And don't tell me that this game is worth more than 50 bucks because it isn't. If I want to play something worth my money I would rather choose something like Guild Wars 2.Good things about this game? The co-op is very enjoyable, the ranking system is fun, the arcade system is basically an (almost) endless mode of instances and crafting could be better, a little complexity here and there won't hurt.Rating (from someone you don't know/care about) = 5/10.Hell, not enough energy to rate higher. Sorry.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 11, 2014
												Background ethos: I have a playtime of 55:07:28:52, linked is an alt account. I've been a customer of OOO since 2007. I 'jumped ship' from Y!PP to this game in 2012.This game is a hard sell. It is fun, vibrant and is both simple enough to pick up, and compelling enough to not put down. 2 years ago, I would say that once you get over the mist system, it's an excellent game I hope to see grow to be even better. 2 years later, I cannot reccommend this game wholeheartily due to the missteps it has taken. There is no getting past the top-heavy 'first act' of the game, restricting leveling system, redundancy-by-proxy mission system, and lack of an endgame.These decisions and the overall lack of content to explore being added in any fashion sour the game experience for me. While the game remains something I come back to, I can no longer tell my friends to try it out, and I won't tell you, reader, either.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 7, 2013
												Play this game.It's a dungeon crawler MMORPG with a dash of zelda inserted for good measure. The old 'free' mist energy may have been scrapped, but so have energy costs for elevators and alchemy. In short, buying energy with real money is now a shortcut, not a necessity. It's perfectly possible to play through the entire main game (i.e. the 'rank' missions) completely free.There are no 'character levels', but your equipment gains 'heat' (basically exp), and after a certain amount is collected, you can level it up via the forge. Weapons 'evolve' through alchemy, and new weapons can be crafted via alchemy.The main game has you play as a knight who completes various missions which revolve around exploring what is known as the clockworks and fighting various monsters there. Rank missions involve you exploring 2-3 levels of the clockworks each time, whereas using the arcade lets you explore more freely - once you've done enough rank missions, you can go from 'depth 0' to 'depth 29' in a single run.The levels within the clockworks get progressively harder as you go deeper, and there are four main bosses to kill (as many times as you want) - and that's not including the difficult 'shadow lairs'. I feel that there's an emphasis on teamwork throughout the game (working as a team to complete missions makes it easier and you still get the same drops) and somewhat on player skill later on (even with excellent equipment, you'll still die if you're bad with a shield).It should be said, however, that if you don't wish to fork out any cash for energy, then you may find that the grinding required to advance throughout the game may prove too repetitive and boring - experienced MMO players probably won't suffer from this issue, however.Overall, I'd say this is a great game for those who enjoy MMOs, exploration and adventure. Me gusta.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 20, 2014
												Playing for free in Spiral Knights can be summed up thusly, Grindan: The Grindaning. To even upgrade your equipment, you have to go through the same level repeatedly for a slim chance that a rare upgrading ingredient might drop, or you can grind for money and buy another type of premium currency to buy the ingredient. Pets are useless, especially in the first 30 levels where they have a lack of skill points. The storyline is just an excuse for your characters to go grind some more in the dungeons. You can also spend real money to skip all that grinding and get to the good stuff, like weapons, boss fights, and accessories.Otherwise, it is a nice little rpg with weapon trees, good controls, cute pets, costumes, accessories, trading ingame premium money, and all that classic junk you would expect from a mmorpg these days. Even if grinding is a large part of the game, 7/10 would reccomend again.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 4, 2012
												I've recently realized that this game satisfies a lot of my completionist tendencies, sort of like smaller games 'Upgrade Complete' and 'DLC Quest'. Not to say that Spiral Knights plays anything like those two - it's very much it's own animal. Essentially, I'd call the game a fast-paced adventure in dungeon-running, where the monsters spawn intent on ruining your day and your reflexes and gear are all you've got to defeat them. And gear - oh, the gear. You gather materials from the monsters you beat in the dungeons, and craft them into bigger and better weapons, armor and accessories. Which you then use to become stronger, rank up, and wreck more monsters. Plus, everything you craft appears in wonderful detail on your character: a nice visual nod to all the work you do. All this makes it that much sweeter to jump in, party up and make the Clockworks beg for mercy.

												I've been playing this game, on and off, long before it was released on Steam, since beta.  I played opening release weekend, late March 2011. Story is weak.If you're a casual player that can only log on for less than an hour to two hours a day to play, you'll find lots to do in this game without it feeling too grindy.  If you have more time to play than that per day, you'll get bored of this game relatively fast.

												Spiral knights is (for me) a very enjoyable game. Before you dive into it though, I must warn you it might be addicting for some. The game has graphics which make the game look cute but amazing at the same time, and the soundtrack always fits prefectly with it. Some people might argue there might be no point in playing once you get full 5* gear and all the stuff. Lately (about a month ago) I found that was wrong. That is because you can always RP or invent games within the game, like what the arsenal podcast did. I think this is an amzing game, but be wary to not get addicted to playing it. So I recommend this game, but not too much so you won't get addicted.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 4, 2014
												I have only recently linked my Spiral Knights account to steam, this is why it says i have played very little. I have played 200+ hours off steam.Spiral Knights is a very well designed and addictive mmo, not exactly the most complex one ever, but a excellent game never the less. It has had many changes during the time i have played this game that can change elements of the game completley, some good, some bad, but not bad enough to stop me playing.PROSA Great Variety of EnemiesCustomisation optionsLevels (depths)WeaponsAreasCharacters (Npcs)Players (online)MissionsOther FeaturesCrafting systemGame modes (Lockdown, etc)Guilds (clans, groups)Great bosses and boss battles (Snarbloax, Vanaduke)(Fairly new) Sprites (Pets that can fight with you)Beautifully designed Stages and areasAmazing soundtrack (availible on Itunes and Spotify)Runs pretty well on non-powerfull PC's and LaptopsAnd much more i have probably missedCONSMay take a while to get/craft/upgrade items (not so much now after a big update)Levels may get repetetive (not in my opinion)Some missions can be very difficult (but optional)Probably a few points i have missed but this game hardly has any bad points.One of if not my fave game (ever)9/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 23, 2012
												I do not play MMORPGs, so it's special when I say I play Spiral Knights. It's kept extremely simple, which makes it a great casual game that I can pick up and drop off without intense involvement. This is a good pizza-and-mouse game, meaning you can play one-handed due to the simplicity of the controls. It's a nice, calm, relaxing game, with stretches of tension and frustration. It's FtP, so there's limits on how much you can do in a 24 hour span, which kind of helps keeps me from seeing the limitations of the campaign missions. The skirmish missions are always different, but to clear a campaign, you must fight the same enemies on the same map. It has a difficulty spike in some areas. I love the visual design, and the music is an awesome combination of eight-bit and chill. Some of the collecting and trading aspects are difficult, as it isn't always easy to find someone who will buy what you want, even though it is extremely easy to buy items from others at the sub-ten tiers.  8.5/10.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 18, 2015
												Graphics - 8/10 - Shockingly Stunning - The game has a lot of equipment that draws a different look here and there, and lots of outfits and pieces to deck you out... But there's a feel, something about the game manages to pull out a cartoony, fun, adventurous look that just makes you want to play more and explore despite it's instance system.Gameplay - 8/10* - Spectacular~! Note*: Simplistic at best, hack and slash, kite and run, reminds me of a MOBA but an adventurous and rpg'like form. Kinda lacks in a sense for auto-combos which isn't customizable (Assign'ed based on the item).Community - 5/10 - Lacking~!? The community is lacking; I try to communicate, ask for help and furthermore and rarely if anyone ever communicates.Customization - 8.25/10 - Just play and you'll understand, You can change nearly anything to really own your "Spiral Knight", however sometimes forced to wear certain items due to stat limitations. A lot of the custom pieces to add to equipments cost a penny, or hard to get. Colors are there, only thing I see lacking is patterns that can be added (They have patterns, but locked on specific items/labeled items).Replayability 7.25/10 - The game got me hooked pretty well, but some reason I cannot find a reason to come back. After playing 3 hours straight, and 2 more sessions of an hour and a half.. I stopped playing, I assume it's cause at one point or another it feels too "Starter RPG-Game" to me, but nonetheless it's a notable game and I'd recommend it to all ages of my family and friends.Overall 7.3/10- "Great Game" - I feel what dropped it's rating is the sole-fact it's so simple to pick up, it's so easy to play, and accomodates everything you'd expect in a RPG.. However, it lacks a open-world, the discovery factor; Or something else such as a unique system of any sort to bring something new to the table to truly "Cling onto you".However the game does what it's supposed too- Very fun as it does, and can drag you on for endless of time if you don't watch that timer. Over and out,-V.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 30, 2011
												Spiral Knights is a throw back to old school action rpg platformers, and in my opinion is most similar to the Zelda franchise (Zelda 4 swords adventure in particular). The core gameplay is casual but also fun and addictive. The graphics, while certainly nothing to brag about, are more than adequate to provide a smooth gaming experience while not looking too outdated. The music is both melodic and reminiscent of the good old 8bit days. There are some minor lag problems due to the games use of UDP protocols and because of the limmited server size, however, the game is still in ongoing development and there's no reason to think these issues won't be rectified in the future. All in all I'd recommend Spiral Knights to anyone and give it a 4/5 rating.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 6, 2015
												So Spiral Knights... I played back in ye olde days before the steam release. For quite a while actually. months of playtime, possibly half a year. I went through the hell that was the CANT LOG IN phase in the game, stopping me from playing for a couple of weeks, which really killed me. That event seriously injured the game, and if I remember, wasa caused by some hacking over at Sega (but dont quote me on that). This little paragraph was just a backstory to what I've been through with this game, just to let you know that I LOVE this game, or atleast used to more than I do now, so the actual review is down below... One last thing, I have not played this game in over a year, but I've looked at the update logs and such, so I atleast know what's happened.Alright, the pros of this game. The gameplay itself is basic, but not mind-numbingly boring. You move around, attack, pick things up, dodge, etc. Better than most MMO's today, with all that clicking on something to blindly attack whatever bull. The art style of the game is quite nice. The soundtrack...boy, I REALLY like the soundtrack, one of my favorite things about this game. The community (in-game, why this is will be said later...) is probably one of the best things about this game. I made many in-game friends playing this game, some in particular were very nice and cool. And as I see in other reviews, Im not alone. The shop that drives the economy is the auction house, where you can put things up for crowns (currency). There are npc vendors, but I'll be honest, no one uses them, unless they have something unique.Alright, now the bad stuff, the stuff I really hate to see. In the old days of Spiral Knights, there was mist energy. It regenerated quite slowly up to a maximum of 100. Elevators in the game were used to continue on through the levels, but cost 10 energy to use. So that's basically 10 levels a day, maybe around 12 if you use it at specific times. Crystal energy is considered the premium currency in this game, since every f2p game ever has to have one. But on one fateful day, mist energy was removed, but elevators are now free to use. This was a very smart decision, I thought, except when the rest of the update was revealed. Originally, to craft things, pretty much the only way to get high tier gear, you used energy and materials dropped from enemies. You would also pick up heat for your gear, which is used to level it up and make it better. But then, they added Orbs of Alchmey and Fire Shards. Orbs weren't that awful for me, but only because the game requires you to have a certain level weapon in order to craft the next tier of weapon. With the new fire shards, you had to have a specific fire shard, and depending on the amount you used, would show a percentage that the heat level up would be succesful. So you had to have lady luck on your side unless you want to potentially waste all your crystals on one of 10 heat levels (the max). Basically, the game became a grindfest for orbs and shards (and I didnt mention that lower grade shards cant be combined to make bigger shards, but bigger shards can be smashed into smaller ones. BUT you had to have the recipe to do that, which was given to you when you completed the gear check once you had all the same tier gear. Ex: Full tier 4 gear check, you go through, you can now get tier 5 gear. You get a recipe for smashing tier 5 shards, the ones you need, for tier 4 shards, the ones you USED to need. The system is very broken, and I dont think its changed at all.)Before missions, there was the arcade, a place where gateways led to branches of levels, and players could influence which levels showed up in next weeks gates. This was were you went to actually PLAY the game. That always struck me as interesting. But when the missions came out, you could just skip all those levels and go straight to the boss levels, the main reason people were going down certain gates. Sure, it saved time and wasnt as much as a pain to get there, but missions literally KILLED the arcade. I dont see anyone there anymore, even though it still exists. I just feel it takes some exploration out of the game.But what about the crystals? Now they're used for feeding your pet, which you get through a line of missions. Everyone freaked out at this since every MMO must ALWAYS have pets. When they came out, you could choose a mini dragon that shoots fire, a phantom ghost that shot out caustic needles and could go invisible, and a cat. You know, just a  cat that flies around. Guess which one no one ever picked...(the cat). Thing is, once I got my pet, I used him some, leveled him up a bit, but I always forgot about him. I never used him as often as he was intended, even though when I did remember him, he did help some. Doesn't this show that we have come to not need pets? We played the game to work as a team of knights traversing through the unknown depths of an alien planet, cut off from the rest of our home. Now its more like pet simulator.And last but CERTAINLY not least, the new updates. I looked at over 30 update logs within the past year or so. All but about 2 had ACTUAL content. The rest of them were just adding limited time reskins of cosmetics, that cost money to get. This is just sad...  this isnt tf2.Ok, so I sound like I dont like this game right? Well, I dont like what its become. I liked it before, (except for the elevators becoming free, that was the best thing ever) where it was actually different from other games. Like I said, I love this game, and I hate to see it die like this.TL;DR (because i'll be honest, this review is frickin long) The game is fun, enjoyable, and all around a cool experience, although its taken some turns for the worst. I wouldnt want to see this game die, since it seems to be bleeding out right now. But overall I give this game a 7/10, or if nostalgia is added to the equation, 8/10. This game is a fantastic f2p, and I recommend it to anyone who is willing to try it out. Do note that the bad things kick in later in the game. You can enjoy the game starting out up til then.Thank you for reading, and I hope you enjoy Spiral Knights.

This game is all about going through levels, trying to reach the centre of the planet, and as you do, the enemies become harder to beat and the levels take more skill and better geat to survive. (though there would be different enemies and in different places) This game also has some puzzle elements too. there is also a PvP mode called Lockdown, which is fun, but I personally don't like it, as you have to have really good geat to even stand a chance. number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 9
												Before we begin, I have a bunch more hours into this game, but just played off of steam. (400-something)Bragging about my low amount of hours ingame aside, this game is kind of like TF2. Not in the sense of gameplay, but in the sense of new content. That is, there isn't much new stuff happening. The last new weapons were added in 2014. Since the players control energy prices, energy has gone up to around 11K crowns, which is very difficult for newer players to obtain. Heck, the original developers of the game aren't even there anymore. That being said, I sincerely enjoy and recommend this game. Why? Read on...Graphics are good, especially for a 2011 700MB game.  The enemies are designed to have clearly choreographed attacks, not to make it easy, but so you can learn how to dodge, time, and intercept attacks. The enemies get harder the farther you go, so learning those moves early on can save you a bunch of sparks of life later on. The point is that this game isn't just a point-and-click fiesta, but has decent amount of skill involved. I have never encountered a cheater or hacker, and the community, in my biased opinion, is one of the better ones out there. Grinding is a large part of the game, but the arcade levels are random and always different. (Unless you replay the same one 6 times because the treasure vault is right th-oops) This grinding does take a long time, and if you go to the recipie vendor, and he doesn't have your recipie, tough luck. gotta do the levels again. But you obtain loot and shinies along the way, so at least you get those should your recipie not be there. Another thing this game has is character. The weapons are cool, there's a ton of different armors, shields, and weapons, AND HATS. The levels are fun, and not too repetitive, and finally finding that Sacred Grizzly Pathfinder helm recipie is... well, I don't know. I'm still looking for that one. :) But crafting weapons after finding the recipie and leveling it up makes you feel pretty good, and getting that new sprite perk is always cool.Remember how I said new content was slow? It is. not gonna lie. However, it has been inproving. Grey Havens, the new guys, have been doing a pretty good job fixing stuff and adding small new things into the game. (I spent far too many crowns at the Slime Casino) Now would be the time to try the game out rather than 2 years ago, in terms of content. They have yet to add new levels, or anything big to the game yet, but I think they're gonna do fine. Once you complete the campaign (which is fairly long, including required grinding for stuff) you still have guilds, acades, and more to do. In summary, Spiral Knights is a fun 3rd person MMO that's free to play, has a good community, and will certainly keep you busy for a while. While there isn't an incredible amount of new stuff to the game, it's slowly getting there, and Grey Havens does care about the game. AND THERE'S HATS!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 16, 2014
												Being a fan of RPG games, I started playing SK with an open mind.. when I started I wasn't too sure how much I would enjoy the gameplay, but after a while (and a few rank-ups and gear changes) I really started enjoying Spiral Knights.Based on a Micro-transaction income model, this Free-to-play RPG is exactly what is says. Free-To-Play.Meaning, you CAN play for free.. but a lot of the beginning grind can be removed with a few small purchases of the ingame "Energy", which can help you develop your gear faster and start earning more of the ingame currency, "Crowns".Saying that, the game CAN be completely Free-to-Play if you choose. Be prepaired to run some of the lower levels quite a lot as you try and rank your gear up.I would recommend researching different types of weapons and armor in the game. At the beginning you are provided a large variety of weapons via Missions, which reflect the different weapon types, and different variations of each weapon (Swords, Guns and Bombs).-Pro's:Easy going, Fun, and the community is generally very friendly.-Con's:can take a little while to get started, and at the beginning earning Crowns can seem very difficult. this is all part of the learning curve of the game, and any necessary purchases in the game will correlate to the mission rewards that you get. If you don't waste your crowns when you start, then you will be fine... But it's very important to not waste crowns on useless things you do not need at the beginning.Overall, I have played SK for around 2 months now. I started playing standalone, and then switched my account to the Steam version. I managed to reach the highest rank, Vanguard, and STILL enjoy playing the game. That's a hard thing for a game to achieve in my eyes, and I believe they have been successful with this.

content:
Posted: September 19, 2011
												I, like many reviewers, played this game for the first time back in 2012, when updates were common, parties were full, and Mist Energy was a thing.  Due to various circumstances however, I stopped playing for quite some time.  It wasn't until recently that I got back into the game, and I haven't really gotten much farther in the story.As I mentioned in my review previously, I think battle sprites are a welcome addition, much like the removal of Crystal Energy.  The big points in my previous review still stand.However, that's not to say I don't have any issues with the game.  I think more levels and more weapons are necessary.  Perhaps a new weapon class?  No idea.  I am also of the opinion that Heat Crystals are a problem.  There are two solutions I can see.  Either drop them entirely, or at least make them more common.  My helm has been sitting at level 7 for at least a month of near-solid play.  I don't mind Alchemy Orbs, but Heat Crystals need some work.The game needs some tweaks, but it's still pretty good.  It's worth a try at least, and hey, it's free.  Why not?

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 11, 2016
												First off: This is honestly the best free-to-play game you will find on Steam.The graphics are intuitive and maintain the perfect balance between realism and cartoonishness. The community is incredibly nice and supportive (hello, Dota 2?) and the possibilities to play with others are endless.One of the best things about this game is that even if you replay a mission over and over again, the scenario and map you are put into is never the same. There's an infinite number of possible map layouts for every mission, and the missions always have something different that makes that certain mission special and unique. Another major plus is that it requires no grinding/farming to achieve the highest level, and even once you have the best gear and have completed all of the regular missions, there's still so much you can do. There's room to have up to three games on one account so you can always start anew, and if you really think you've accomplished everything there is to accomplish on one game, you can always delete it and start again, opening up another new world of possibilities and game-changing decisions to experiment with.Being a Youtuber (PeaceOfMined), the guild and party options are incredibly useful and fun to record on, especially with the voice-sync (although it is kind of slow). The armor and sword combinations are endless, and with the battle sprites and all the different skills and compositions in one party comes a feeling that you're playing the perfect blend of Spiral Knights and League of Legends, where you have all the abilities and attack possibilities of League, and along with it have the intuitive control system, open-world feeling, and extra attacking options of Spiral Knights, as well as the manual team composition and chatting system.One last thing is the addictiveness of the game itself. I'm a full time student as well as a musician, Youtuber and athlete. What you may notice is I seem to have more hours on record than would seem possible with a schedule like that. I agree. Spiral Knights is a very addicting game. If you have a steady job, be prepared to leave Spiral Knights for a week, as you won't like it one bit.Me: Mom can I take a short break from my homeworkMom: Sure you've been at it for three hoursMe: *opens Spiral Knights*Mom: (seven hours later) Are you done your homework yet? It's past midnightMe: Yeah just a secondMe: *the next morning* Hey mr. teacher I couldn't finish my homework last nightTeacher: WhyMe: I was trainingTeacher: You were playing Spiral KnightsMe: How can you tellTeacher: Im secretly your friend on steam and i was in your party for five hours straightMe: subscribe to my channelTeacher: Already doneMe: Jesus christ what have you been doing with your lifeTeacher: Spiral Knights ;DI challenge you to find a better PC open-world dungeon crawler, paid or not. Comment on my Spiral Knights YouTube videos if you find one I should review. (https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCXN5MB1UIN1aH2FRw-rPV9g)Overall Rating (There's no infinity symbol on the keyboard):  infinity/10subscribe :D

content:
Posted: January 26, 2016
												A hidden gem among the f2p genre. The unique graphics, great soundtracks, and the slash and hack combat system makes this a fun game alone or with friends. The only problems with the game is the fact that the game is literally never updated anymore after the lead developer Nick left the team. Also, the endgame is horribly boring and the only thing left to do is to look prettier with costumes or go play PvP. The fun in the game is the journey to endgame, not reaching endgame. I highly reccommend to play the missions and arcade with friends otherwise it could get a bit boring.

content:
Posted: July 7, 2014
												If you are into MMOs, or are interested in getting into one, definitely give Spiral Knights a try.Many MMOs follow the same format, consisting of endless numbers of "fetch" or "collect" quests, where all you do is grind against monsters, hoping that they will drop the item you need progressively more ridiculous amounts of.In Spiral Knights, there actually is a good amount of variety in the available missions. The story also provides a healthy amount of cutscenes if and text if you are looking for that. Missions typically involve you progressing through a dungeon littered with enemies and different types of square voxels of differing types (ex: wall voxel or explosive voxel). There are sometimes gates that require you to pick up a key (you cannot attack while carrying it) and bring it to the padlock in order to open it. You might also have to pick up a pot object and throw it at another object in order to clear obstacles, allowing for further access into a dungeon.The combat and controls are pretty easy to become familiar with. Left click to attack, right click to use your shield. Holding the attack down allows you to charge up your weapon (a gauge will appear). You may also use the mouse wheel to alternate between weapons. There is a dash/evade mechanic you can execute by holding shift and pressing right click. The dungeons can become fairly challenging if playing solo, however, it is still viable if you are careful and do not rush right into enemy spawns. The rewards from completing missions and item drops are reasonable. The loot automatically is attracted to your character like a magnet, so you do not need to click on dropped items.Aesthetics are nice, the dungeons and enemies are decently detailed. Like many MMOs, there can be a lot of clutter in the interface, especially when you first log into the game and access the game hub - you will need to get used to this orientation if you have not played many MMOs. The minimap can be expanded to cover the center of your screen by pressing B (do not press tab, that brings up the character stats/info panel), however, be advised that the border of the map is a bold blue, making it noticeably difficult to play while keeping the minimap expanded (compared to games like Path of Exile, or Diablo, where the minimap is translucent enough for you to see most things easily.Overall, the game seems pretty fleshed out, with quite a bit to do. Definitely recommend trying it out if you are interested and/or not already playing other MMOs  (or have the extra time to spare).

content:
Posted: January 9, 2014
												While this game has been recieved rathe negatively by the general public, if you like dodgy space shiz and an overall rather random experience, then this game is quite a good choice for you. I found that while the backstory was very well supported throughout the early game, it could have been used more frequently throughout the later parts of the game as the "bosses" of the tiers seemed to have little relevane to the game itself. So if you're a tickler for hardcore RPGs and intense storylines, maybe disregard this game as a viable option.However, the charming thing about Spiral Knights is the deep multiplayer capabilities. While there is a rather small 250 friend limit (which I easily capped within a few days), the ability to join a guild and "chillax" in your guild hall is rather fun part of this game. Personally, I am crap at the game's actual gameplay but continue to play it for the simple reason to connect with randoms across the globe.Overall, as a gamer I would rate this game a 2/10.However, as a human being I would give it an 8 for my love of the Spiral Knights community.

content:
Posted: June 9, 2013
												A really fun FTP Zelda-like adventure game. While unfortunately the game only allows you to play 10 levels per day (each level costs 10 "Energy", and you have a max of 100 Free energy) the 10 levels is usually enough for a run of the Clockworks, and the difficulty level is placed just right - the game is difficult without being cheap (mostly), I honestly feel challenged as I go up to face the Jelly King with my party (2 3-star people, including myself, and 1 5-star person)Highly recommended, even if the game can be a serious cash grab at times.. although with how enjoyable it is, I'm considering pouring money into it myself.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 7, 2014
												Long ago. 3 years ago, on Aug 27, 2011. I was but a young lad. young, naive, perhaps innocent. In the new world of Spiral Knights. Spiraling down a chasm of confusion and curiosity, I was finally brought up with a recommendation to Spiral Knights. Filled with swords, pistols, shields, parties, dungeons, and list of items The game Spiral knights(SK) from recollection memories during my first journey through it's dungeons and game-play nearly three years ago. Was enjoyable to say the least.If you for one second can imagine an down graphics to appeal to the ages of 7-13 then probably this game is for you. If your into friendship and co-op through dungeons facing monsters with your trusty pistol or sword and shield, then perhaps this game is for you. However, I digress. S.K. proved to be something that is beyond the average you normally see. Imagine yourself a kid, after the game boy era, the ps1 era, the xbox era, and you have an era of mmo games. Granted, mmo's have existed since probably before the age of 2001 with WoW at its center. The mmo S.K. is to be honest short lived game, pulling your slightest attention for the smallest of seconds through promotions with Team Fortress 2. Such was the case for me when I ashamedly downloaded this game for another TF2 hat promo from S.K. Enjoyable in the sense, that I alone played by myself seeking for riches and glory. I didn't expect much, and that is proven by my hours spent on this game. Later on, I played with my friends together in a typical fashion of dungeon crawling and killing bosses. I'd compare SK to Torchlight, however both games are entirely different and this review isn't about a comparison.It's about telling you my experience. As long as you have friends that back you up in this free to play game. You can literally have a good time. There is a grinding system, but only if you devote many of your efforts to getting the best equipment or the best item for you as soon as possible. Though, in my case. I tried to go for higher quality items, but found it too troublesome to do so. Instead I focused on having fun delving into dungeons with friends in co-op. Laughing so hard when we die because of a stupid mistake like getting stuck in a trap. Or perhaps giving cheers for everyone when we all completed an item set or finished a boss. If you like playing short-to-play games for free, and having fun with friends I would definetly reccomend this game for you.After-all it's not often a studio would go so far to diversify itself for Triple A-A-A games in a Free-2-Play manner. Or would they?(Original Post, Aug 27, 2011) Old score 7.29/10 (Re-edited Post Feb. 6, 2014) New score 7.3/10(Score is based off how much I enjoyed playing the game)

content:
Posted: January 9
												Before we begin, I have a bunch more hours into this game, but just played off of steam. (400-something)Bragging about my low amount of hours ingame aside, this game is kind of like TF2. Not in the sense of gameplay, but in the sense of new content. That is, there isn't much new stuff happening. The last new weapons were added in 2014. Since the players control energy prices, energy has gone up to around 11K crowns, which is very difficult for newer players to obtain. Heck, the original developers of the game aren't even there anymore. That being said, I sincerely enjoy and recommend this game. Why? Read on...Graphics are good, especially for a 2011 700MB game.  The enemies are designed to have clearly choreographed attacks, not to make it easy, but so you can learn how to dodge, time, and intercept attacks. The enemies get harder the farther you go, so learning those moves early on can save you a bunch of sparks of life later on. The point is that this game isn't just a point-and-click fiesta, but has decent amount of skill involved. I have never encountered a cheater or hacker, and the community, in my biased opinion, is one of the better ones out there. Grinding is a large part of the game, but the arcade levels are random and always different. (Unless you replay the same one 6 times because the treasure vault is right th-oops) This grinding does take a long time, and if you go to the recipie vendor, and he doesn't have your recipie, tough luck. gotta do the levels again. But you obtain loot and shinies along the way, so at least you get those should your recipie not be there. Another thing this game has is character. The weapons are cool, there's a ton of different armors, shields, and weapons, AND HATS. The levels are fun, and not too repetitive, and finally finding that Sacred Grizzly Pathfinder helm recipie is... well, I don't know. I'm still looking for that one. :) But crafting weapons after finding the recipie and leveling it up makes you feel pretty good, and getting that new sprite perk is always cool.Remember how I said new content was slow? It is. not gonna lie. However, it has been inproving. Grey Havens, the new guys, have been doing a pretty good job fixing stuff and adding small new things into the game. (I spent far too many crowns at the Slime Casino) Now would be the time to try the game out rather than 2 years ago, in terms of content. They have yet to add new levels, or anything big to the game yet, but I think they're gonna do fine. Once you complete the campaign (which is fairly long, including required grinding for stuff) you still have guilds, acades, and more to do. In summary, Spiral Knights is a fun 3rd person MMO that's free to play, has a good community, and will certainly keep you busy for a while. While there isn't an incredible amount of new stuff to the game, it's slowly getting there, and Grey Havens does care about the game. AND THERE'S HATS!

content:
Posted: January 29, 2015
												This game is one of my very favourites. Essentially you are a Knight. With a sword, sheild and armour. And a gun and a bomb. This game is all about going through levels, trying to reach the centre of the planet, and as you do, the enemies become harder to beat and the levels take more skill and better geat to survive. There are some reused levels but that makes it feel familiar and it makes it easier to navigate. (though there would be different enemies and in different places) This game also has some puzzle elements too. there is also a PvP mode called Lockdown, which is fun, but I personally don't like it, as you have to have really good geat to even stand a chance. There is another PvP mode called Blast Network, which is just like bomberman and doesn't require good gear or weapons, as it doesn't affect gameplay. There is a bunch of character customization and HEAPS of weapons and armour, and a bunch of other stuff I couldn't think of straight off the top of my head... so give it a go!
