number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 16, 2014
												Being a fan of RPG games, I started playing SK with an open mind.. when I started I wasn't too sure how much I would enjoy the gameplay, but after a while (and a few rank-ups and gear changes) I really started enjoying Spiral Knights.Based on a Micro-transaction income model, this Free-to-play RPG is exactly what is says. Free-To-Play.Meaning, you CAN play for free.. but a lot of the beginning grind can be removed with a few small purchases of the ingame "Energy", which can help you develop your gear faster and start earning more of the ingame currency, "Crowns".Saying that, the game CAN be completely Free-to-Play if you choose. Be prepaired to run some of the lower levels quite a lot as you try and rank your gear up.I would recommend researching different types of weapons and armor in the game. At the beginning you are provided a large variety of weapons via Missions, which reflect the different weapon types, and different variations of each weapon (Swords, Guns and Bombs).-Pro's:Easy going, Fun, and the community is generally very friendly.-Con's:can take a little while to get started, and at the beginning earning Crowns can seem very difficult. this is all part of the learning curve of the game, and any necessary purchases in the game will correlate to the mission rewards that you get. If you don't waste your crowns when you start, then you will be fine... But it's very important to not waste crowns on useless things you do not need at the beginning.Overall, I have played SK for around 2 months now. I started playing standalone, and then switched my account to the Steam version. I managed to reach the highest rank, Vanguard, and STILL enjoy playing the game. That's a hard thing for a game to achieve in my eyes, and I believe they have been successful with this.

Posted: January 26, 2016
												A hidden gem among the f2p genre. The unique graphics, great soundtracks, and the slash and hack combat system makes this a fun game alone or with friends. The only problems with the game is the fact that the game is literally never updated anymore after the lead developer Nick left the team. Also, the endgame is horribly boring and the only thing left to do is to look prettier with costumes or go play PvP. The fun in the game is the journey to endgame, not reaching endgame. I highly reccommend to play the missions and arcade with friends otherwise it could get a bit boring.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 11, 2016
												First off: This is honestly the best free-to-play game you will find on Steam.The graphics are intuitive and maintain the perfect balance between realism and cartoonishness. The community is incredibly nice and supportive (hello, Dota 2?) and the possibilities to play with others are endless.One of the best things about this game is that even if you replay a mission over and over again, the scenario and map you are put into is never the same. There's an infinite number of possible map layouts for every mission, and the missions always have something different that makes that certain mission special and unique. Another major plus is that it requires no grinding/farming to achieve the highest level, and even once you have the best gear and have completed all of the regular missions, there's still so much you can do. There's room to have up to three games on one account so you can always start anew, and if you really think you've accomplished everything there is to accomplish on one game, you can always delete it and start again, opening up another new world of possibilities and game-changing decisions to experiment with.Being a Youtuber (PeaceOfMined), the guild and party options are incredibly useful and fun to record on, especially with the voice-sync (although it is kind of slow). The armor and sword combinations are endless, and with the battle sprites and all the different skills and compositions in one party comes a feeling that you're playing the perfect blend of Spiral Knights and League of Legends, where you have all the abilities and attack possibilities of League, and along with it have the intuitive control system, open-world feeling, and extra attacking options of Spiral Knights, as well as the manual team composition and chatting system.One last thing is the addictiveness of the game itself. I'm a full time student as well as a musician, Youtuber and athlete. What you may notice is I seem to have more hours on record than would seem possible with a schedule like that. I agree. Spiral Knights is a very addicting game. If you have a steady job, be prepared to leave Spiral Knights for a week, as you won't like it one bit.Me: Mom can I take a short break from my homeworkMom: Sure you've been at it for three hoursMe: *opens Spiral Knights*Mom: (seven hours later) Are you done your homework yet? It's past midnightMe: Yeah just a secondMe: *the next morning* Hey mr. teacher I couldn't finish my homework last nightTeacher: WhyMe: I was trainingTeacher: You were playing Spiral KnightsMe: How can you tellTeacher: Im secretly your friend on steam and i was in your party for five hours straightMe: subscribe to my channelTeacher: Already doneMe: Jesus christ what have you been doing with your lifeTeacher: Spiral Knights ;DI challenge you to find a better PC open-world dungeon crawler, paid or not. Comment on my Spiral Knights YouTube videos if you find one I should review. (https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCXN5MB1UIN1aH2FRw-rPV9g)Overall Rating (There's no infinity symbol on the keyboard):  infinity/10subscribe :D

content:
Posted: February 21, 2016
												I love this game. I really do. I've called it 4-swords the mmorpg, because that's what the gameplay feels like. The variety of weapons is fun, and I like how your character doesn't level up- it's all in the gear. The visuals are beautiful and it's not the dreaded "standard fantasy world" setting that so many mmorpgs fall into. the music, too, is fun, and the game presents a decent challenge.However, this game has gone downhill. The grind for items is downright awful, and the economy is tanking fast. The playbase is dwindling, and the devs clearly do not care about this game anymore. I wish it was different, because this game was so fantastic and so fun, but the extreme amounts of grinding on repetitive levels has killed all the fun. With a heavy heart I cannot recommend this game.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 7, 2014
												If you are into MMOs, or are interested in getting into one, definitely give Spiral Knights a try.Many MMOs follow the same format, consisting of endless numbers of "fetch" or "collect" quests, where all you do is grind against monsters, hoping that they will drop the item you need progressively more ridiculous amounts of.In Spiral Knights, there actually is a good amount of variety in the available missions. The story also provides a healthy amount of cutscenes if and text if you are looking for that. Missions typically involve you progressing through a dungeon littered with enemies and different types of square voxels of differing types (ex: wall voxel or explosive voxel). There are sometimes gates that require you to pick up a key (you cannot attack while carrying it) and bring it to the padlock in order to open it. You might also have to pick up a pot object and throw it at another object in order to clear obstacles, allowing for further access into a dungeon.The combat and controls are pretty easy to become familiar with. Left click to attack, right click to use your shield. Holding the attack down allows you to charge up your weapon (a gauge will appear). You may also use the mouse wheel to alternate between weapons. There is a dash/evade mechanic you can execute by holding shift and pressing right click. The dungeons can become fairly challenging if playing solo, however, it is still viable if you are careful and do not rush right into enemy spawns. The rewards from completing missions and item drops are reasonable. The loot automatically is attracted to your character like a magnet, so you do not need to click on dropped items.Aesthetics are nice, the dungeons and enemies are decently detailed. Like many MMOs, there can be a lot of clutter in the interface, especially when you first log into the game and access the game hub - you will need to get used to this orientation if you have not played many MMOs. The minimap can be expanded to cover the center of your screen by pressing B (do not press tab, that brings up the character stats/info panel), however, be advised that the border of the map is a bold blue, making it noticeably difficult to play while keeping the minimap expanded (compared to games like Path of Exile, or Diablo, where the minimap is translucent enough for you to see most things easily.Overall, the game seems pretty fleshed out, with quite a bit to do. Definitely recommend trying it out if you are interested and/or not already playing other MMOs  (or have the extra time to spare).

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 2, 2012
												Spiral Knights is really fun as you're progressing through the mission system. The gameplay is nice, the controls are simple, and the stat system is understandable. Three Rings puts heavy emphasis on co-op play, and it is certainly far more fun with more people.Problem is, Three Rings updates the game slower than molasses going uphill in January with crutches. The only thing that can keep you hooked to the game is a desire(and the money) to do the Shadow Lairs, or a desire to play PvP and the money to be able to do buttshit in it. The only thing that can diversify equipment is a random Unique Variant system, and if you don't have the luck or money to get the best UVs, you might as well not play PvP at all.Still, Spiral Knights is amazing for a F2P. Just don't get overaddicted to it like I did, because once you hit the endgame, you'll be there with nothing to do for a month.

content:
Posted: June 22, 2016
												Alright I'd like to begin this review with a reminder of how long I've played this game. 744 hours! Dang! So I've played this game from 2011 to like 2013 ish. The reason why I quit was because there's this natural barrier that prevents you from putting more hours into this game. What i mean by this is that when you reach to level 4 or 5 gear, there's going to be a TON i mean a TON of grinding. Like im talking about hours and hours of grinding. This basically deterred people from playing this game in general after that. For most people that reach this point just go striaght into PvP however i can say that the Pvp mechanics is great and all but there's no real incentive for poeple to pvp besides the fact that you get cosmetics or recipes for weapons you have to grind even more for.so to sum up:pros: good mechanics: pretty good graphics: good amount of weapon and armor choice: feels like a good rpgcons: :extremely repetitive: extremely time consuming: community is pretty much dead (<1000) : extremely grindy especically with the new system they implemented: updates are all just money grabbers, no real add ons to the game

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 23, 2014
												You're constantly fighting an uphill struggle in this game, this game had so much potential and only limited itself with the energy system. A lot of people feel like this is easily averted, it is, if you are willing to spend a lot of time either playing the Marketplace or crafting items to get the money in order to get more energy. Everything you do requires energy and that's a big flaw, it's like Farmville, you get many small doses of rewards backed by a refresh timer and it just interupts the flow of everything. Ultimately they want you to spend money to buy energy, or somehow grab enough cash to convert into energy which as I said, mostly requires playing the marketplace, and for those who want a clean way of accomplishment then tough luck! That being said, combat was fun and the dungeon crawling aspects were top notch, for the short while I played this game it was a blast, I loved the item system and I liked the fact that you made everything your own through dedication. still though. Paywalls.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 29, 2012
												F2P co-op action-rpg that's fun and easy to play in short bursts, but quickly shows its shallow and repetitive nature. I really like that the battles are real-time, you can defend against or dodge enemy attacks and that player skill and knowledge of elemental strengths/weaknesses become vital later on. Your gear levels up instead of your character by acquiring heat from killing enemies.  It takes Crystal Energy ($) to level up gear among other things, so without a lot of grinding it's hard to stay F2P.  On the bright side the game recently made traveling on the elevators to and within dungeons free. End game has been the same for a long time.  Don't expect new content very frequently. Do expect promotional cash shop "dress up" crap to pop up all the time. All optional of course, but it just shows you it doesn't take long to suck the game's content dry when you can't find people to go on missions with you because they're all standing around town trying on their halos, wings and twinkly auras.

I have to say NO.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 20, 2014
												Mostly finished.Public nowNow don't get me wrong, Spiral Knights USE to be a good game until they made it a real free to play. It is quite obvious that the developers wanted as much money as they could get, so they added Spark's of life, and those heat things that level up your weapons, and made the elevators free just to remove the good co-op in the game. (No shared coins, can't revive party members) God. Why. I actually enjoyed the co-op and even contributed to the game and bought things with money, that won't be happening anytime soon again, unless they fix this terrible new co-op, and new free to play feature)There are still *some* good things in the game, but it is beaten down by the new features. The art style is great, and well done. The fighting is fun, or use to be fun until they removed reviving. The weapons have their own up's and downs, balancing most out. Some things are set up nicely, but the new features do ruin them. There is an auction house to buy things that you want when you can't get them, but have the crowns to get them. That is really all I can think of.The bad features? Well all of the new features. The "mini" monsters. Those things are devils and will ALWAYS kill you. No reviving, little co-op. Coins aren't shared in levels anymore. Sparks of life which cost energy to buy. No more mist energy. Elevators are free, and addition that came with the new features, which means no more elevator passes (I liked the elevator pass system, changed the game into a non-free to play, but now it is a complete free to play, and you can't get out of it). New heat system where leveling up weapons requires crystals which cost money too. Gaining heat on your weapons was hard enough, and now there is a CHANCE for it to level up when you use crystals (Unless you use a load of them which costs even more money)?! The repetitive arena levels and the missions to get to new tiers are really useless. The old tier system was better where you would have to go through a group of levels, not boring missions, and have the correct armor and weapons.As an old player, I DO NOT recommend this game, it was hard enough before, and now they made it even HARDER.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 12, 2015
												First of all when I started playing this game, it was fun. I met some great friends and have a few of them on Steam. The best moment I had is when I reached Vanguard. Now I really don't like this game anymore. I find it a waste of time. All you do in Spiral Knights is the same things everyday that players do. Players just do the same things everyday in this game. Play the same levels everyday. Grind for crowns, orbs, heat, materials everyday.Spiral Knights has lots of bugs and glitches. It really annoys me!!! Makes me so angry! How can an enemy hit you when you block like 1.5 seconds before getting hit. Such a glitch. Wheel Launchers, Trojan's attacks, Lumber's attack are the most glitchy. All the sprites abilities are bugged. Now the monsters on Prestige Missions, I find them OP. When you get hit you lose halve of your health if you have no Vitapods. I think that's ridiculous! The worst Prestige Mission is one with Devliites. Those are my worst monsters and you have to fight hordes of them and they are just too powerful.I'm also sick of Promo Boxes. It's a waste of money just to buy a costume for you knight.To level up your 5 star equipment all the way to level 10 is almost impossible without having to spent hours grinding for Radiants. Otherwise you can choose to buy with energy which is not worth the value. Let's say you are going to spent $10 for 3500 Energy. 50 Radiants cost 800 energy. In total you will get 200 Radiants with 300 energy left. How many times can you level up a 5 star equipment?  Like only 2 times after like level 7!! That's a real waste of money.The servers are poor as well and my Internet connection is fine. The lag is the worst thing in this game. While you are lagging you have no idea what's going on. You see you knight standing but the others are running out of the map. Next moment, DEAD!!! The players also complain at you for not moving or fighting but you are lagging so it's can't be your fault. The worst lag in this game is during a Vana run.Winterfest is a nice event but the missions.... the missions lag sooo badly. It almost impossible to do them.The community in this game is okay but meanful as well. They would only be meanful if you don't do anything but if you lagging, it's can't be your fault. Some players are very nice in this game but there a very few of them in this game. Here's somebody that was rude to me on the first minute of 2015 in my country time. Beezum: "HAPPY NEW YEAR!!!! The other player: "Shut up Beezum it's still 31st here!"Beezum: "Don't tell me to shut up!"The other player: Don't act like a 5 years old!Beezum: It's 12am for me on 1st Jan 2015.Did he have to tell to shut up? NO!!!! That was so unnecessary and rude.The story has as well is also messed up. They still haven't opened the core. Will they ever open core? Probably never!Please never agree with players that say Spiral Knights is the best game ever! It's totally not. It only get like over 1,000 players in-game peak everyday. It's okay to only play the prestige missions everyday on SK or if you play the game once in a while but I don't do that. I would never recommend this game to any of my friends. It's a time waster and has to many bugs, glitches and has little content.

												Nah, this game used to have great quality, even now u'll find it entertaining in  the first 50 - 100, maybe 200 hours. The gameplay, art style, music, this game has it all. But there're many major problems, mostly from its developer:+ First, this game is very item-reliant. Items are also extremely unbalanced, u'll find details in other reviews.+ Soon the game will become quite repetitive, and it's not anything like Mario or Zelda.+ 2 years; if not more there wasn't a _single_ update.+ Any constructive comments will be ignored/banned/silenced. No matter how calm/polite you are. Their community managers are active, but they will just try to act cute.+ For matured gamers, this game has many cute kids. But that comes along with many arrogant, ill-mannered teenagers.+ And that's just to name a few.So in general, if u have good friends & are looking for a good co-op game to play once in a while, this one is for you. But if u look for something to stay with, then dont. Absolutely, dont.

content:
Posted: January 30, 2016
												First, I'd like to say that I've played 507 hours of this game[tinypic.com] in the downloadable client, so please don't take my 1.4 hours on record too seriously.The PVE gets boring and repetitive after a while, given that there are very few missions are worth doing save for advancing in the questline. However, it does last for some time(around a hundred hours) and for that bit is is a delightful experience. If that's all you're going to do, I suggest you play another game.The best part of this game is... dressup. I'm not going to lie. Development on this game for the most part has been centered on creating more and more costumes for players to use, and other things like PVE and general gameplay has been left behind. With that in mind, costumes are now cooler and better looking than ever, and surpass other aspects of this game. This opens up many opportunities for players. Here are some examples of costumes I've been using:1[i.imgsafe.org] 2[i.imgsafe.org]Another great part of this game is the social aspect. Players in this game are often kind, helpful, and interesting individuals. If you get in a large guild of any kind, you could treat this as a medium for general chatting and socializing.Maybe you're wondering what I did in those 400 hours that I didn't spend doing PVE. Well, I was trading. Trading is a fun experience, especially reselling. All of my equipment and costumes came from buying items(specifically 5* sprite food) at half of what it's worth and selling it at market price. I've spent days on end simply just zone chatting various different offers, and while eventually I got bored with it- it was wonderful while it lasted.All in all, I suggest you play this game. Don't let the negative reviews get to you, there is very little harm in trying out a free to play game.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 30, 2015
												If you have friends who are willing to play this game with you, then ignore this review and play the game.Although I only have very few hours on this game, be assured I had much more before I had steam and I downloaded this game from the internet. It's golden time was in the spring of 2013 when people really enjoyed spending all their mist energy (ancient version of crystal energy which charged throughout the day/night and was used for the elevators in the levels) and then going to haven to trade all their loot. In the summer of 2013 a big update came along which changed the UI and the supply depot (kozma used to sell cobalt-azure stuff instead of everything, very useful) and also introduced the mission system and the forge system. It also made trips to the clockworks free so mist energy was removed from the game. Although many players liked this, most didn't because it meant the game had lost it bare-bones feel by replacing it with missions and CE purchases and grinding which ruined the game. Before this massive update, when starting the game you had to customize your character, do the basic tutorial and cross the chasm into haven, from there you were left to explore the rest of the game with the help of those who already knew. After the update, missions led to the trashy lore with razwog and other crappy characters as opposed to finding out yourself. The missions meant that visiting the clockworks was child's play and took away the dark souls difficulty to getting recon modules and finding out about what the game was about. Before the update, to buy exclusive and special items, you had to either find them yourself from boss tokens or trade at the AH for them, afterwards you could buy them more expensively from the supply depot with used to be home to the azure tree which was only available from kozma and the AH. AH prices boomed and became unpopular due to the supply depot, people could find and beat bosses by using the missions which eventually led to the tier system being demolished (the tier system was a system in the clockworks which prevented new players from farming too much and meant that it was at least possible for the tier 3 player to be able to spend his mist energy on the levels they want to farm). The forge system meant players had to constantly grind and forage the clockworks for pointless rocks which level up items, which led to players getting fed up and buying it for real money as opposed to just looting the clockworks the hard way and levelling up your items as you went along, which meant it was easier to build and buy new items. Lockdown and Bomber was introduced which was pretty pointless except for guildwars and general showing off items, after the clockworks were deemed unusable, people turned to lockdown and bomber which now is 99.99% of the game. The devs gave up after half the community left by the end of the year. No new items were introduced anymore, just the same old specials being rerun after that. Also, pointless costumes being introduced. The lore was ruined, the bare-bones feel was taken away, people didn't need or want to trade anymore and PVP was the only way out. People who couldn't keep up or wouldn't keep up decided to leave along with the devs who bailed on the game with the money they made. By mid 2014 there were only 10% of what used to be the amount of people playing. International servers were empty and 'active' guilds only had 2-3 players. The game as of the end of 2015 is now dead, there are only around 200 people playing at midday which is the peak of people online at the same time. For anyone new or old who doesn't have any friends willing to play SK along with them, leave this game alone, the devs killed it.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 21
												A while back I used to play it a lot. This was way before I even had a Steam account. Or maybe I just didn't play it on here. But after a few years, or maybe more, the game has lost what it used to be. Most negative reviews can explain it in detail, but what I am saying here is that many players who played the game before things like missions and pets knew how fun and exciting it actually used to be, as it wasn't about grinding or paying to get items, instead it was more about teamwork and parties going as deep into the dungeon as they could before dying or running out of energy.Sadly the game lost what it used to be, though it's music and art remains to be some of the best I ever had seen in games. If it ever were to be revived in another game, hopefully they would be able to get the original developer working on it again, as if I recall he is what made the whole game feel magical.

												Installed it. Played for 10 hours in one sitting. GG.It's a really addicting arpg/hack n slash. If you're a fan of those genres, install the game. Yes, it's reptetitive, but it makes up for it in the battles(in my opinion). It's fun to block, dodge and kite enemies around on the harder levels. number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 14, 2015
												Now, I don't usually write reviews for games, I stick to playing them. But this game is just way too good to not review it. Keep in mind that this is my first review and if you see something out of place, just ignore it.Now then. I was always a fan of dungeon crawler games, games such as Dungeon Hunter (for the iPad). This game fits very well into this category. Most dungeons are desigened beautifully, and the Boss battles at the end are innovative and fit well with the theme of this game. Most items can also be acquired without spending too much money, and each item has it's own uses, strengths, and weaknesses Though I still love the bombs. The story line of the game is also well thought out and extremely detailed. If you haven't played this game, and you should, for your sake the spoilers of the storyline are going to be set as spoiler text. You can mouse over it if you wish to read what it says. The games story starts off by telling you that you are stranded on an alien planet with new fauna and flora, and immediatley throws you into a tutorial. Now, I don't know about you but I LOVE when the tutorial and the story get mixed together. Any how I am going to stop talking about the stroy since it is best if you experience it for yourself.The games weapons are plentiful, and are again, well designed and innovative. You can upgrade your weapons as well, in a way similar to Dungeon Hunter 5. I am going to finish by saying this game is beautiful, and I see a lot of other reviews talking about it using promos to keep alive, and such. The game has a huge fanbase, and even though it is doing that, it is still worth playing. People are saying money needs to be spent because it is a pay to win game. Not really. Most of the items are available without paying. I definetly recommend this game, especially to fans of the dungeon crawler genre. Thank you for reading my review.

content:
Posted: June 19, 2015
												Game summary:-you don't level up, your gear do from 1 to 5 stars, after investing stuff to transform it :)-all your gear means a helm, an armor, a weapon (but can carry up to 4), a shield, 2 trinkets and a pet with a collar. In your stash you can have more armors, helms, etc  :)-you start from surface and via elevators you go underground levels (very small areas, like 3 minutes of walking from edge to edge). "Highest" depth was 29 last time I played. That is the end. Then you go out and go again same route or another to earn extra money or just because you are too bored and there is nothing else to do  :)-it has missions. You can redo most of them, meaning clearing some depths again.-very fast your gear will be at maximum level. Then you can gamble your in game money (that can be obtained also with real life cash) to get extra options on your gear, like poison defense low, medium, etc, or maximum - meaning better than smaller versions but still not too much :)   This fun part translates into playing the deepest levels again and again and again untill you have enough money to gamble thirth option on a item. Then you do it again and again and again, becauselast time was a rubbish option and you gamble again to replace it hoping for a maximum :)-after a while, even gambling for options is over, when you did the deepest missions so many times that you know where to wait every monster before it spawns. All your party members, friends and guild mates are also in same situation. Now it's time for the cosmetic investments :) A moustache or a pair of glasses, or maybe a feather or an antenna. You may do this earlyer, investing your money in a glowing necklace instead of a better armor. This way you look cooler while you lie dead on your back  :)-OK, now you have everything. Er... well... you do some more runs from top to deepest level. You earn money... Then... you sell some materials..for more money :). Sometimes devs invent new accesories. They drop from boxes that can be buyed with real money. If you buy the box and drops something you don't like you can sell it in auction for in game money. This way other players can have the thrilling experience of wearing a pipe with a brand new yellow, unlike the green, grey and brown that existed before the summer promotion :)-You start the game. Hm... Nothing new, except the guild leader message to donate more money to the guild to pay rent for guild rooms :)   Your trinket and weapon slots expired, but you buy them again for 1 month each. You do a run with 2 beginners to help them untill they abandon the run and leave you alone at depth 4 :). You try to join a party at biggest boss: Vana, that drops the most expensive tokens. Here you can show off how good is your gear and how impressive you refined your devastating skills. Hi hi :)  Except you can hardly find anyone playing anymore... what happened to the guys?-You start the game... Same old guild message... No guildies online... 1/86 friends online... What to do now? You look at auction, but you have everything. You are bored of all the missions and all levels that you know like the back of your hand. Maybe you do one for old times sake.  It used to be fun before. Exit game disapointed.-Start game. Look around. Do nothing for 5 minutes, because there is nothing to do. You are too bored of killing the same wolfs or zombies that you killed tousands of times. Exit game after 10 minutes withot doing anything.-Start the game... Look around few minutes... Nothing there... Hm... Hm... Exit game.

Posted: June 10, 2015
												I recommend this game for the following reasons:Positive:-Great range of monsters to fight.-Difficulty settings are good to re-do missions.-The speed and graphics of the game run smoother than I thought.-Gives you a broad and unique selection when picking your character.-You can create multiple characters (this helps when your bored with your previous ones)-Love the friend system. So easy to go to friends instead of complicatedly finding them.Negative:-Crashing at some points, sometimes when completing a floor on a dungeon and when I click to choose the reward it crashes.-The community isn't the greatest for me. I know this isn't a problem with the game itself, but the community DOES lack in kindness.-Not a good range of weapons in the store. All they do is improve on the weapons that you get on a level (e.g, the Zapper. in the store there is 2 other versions of it and both give more impact on 'Shocking' the enemy. This doesn't really cut it's deal with the money.) When I was new to the game I payed £6.99 for a gun that A. I can't use until rank 8-1 and B. Doesn't do anything different.-Make it clearer about the ranking when buying things from the store. Possibly restrict people from buying the guns or swords etc. until they reach the rank, a warning on the top isn't good enough.In the end, I do recommend this game. Even though I wasted some money, it's a good game to just play with your friends. Not many games have the friending and party systems, love the uniqueness of this game.~Demonic

												Spiral Knights is a extremly fun 3rd person Hack and Slash game where you play as a race of Cyborgs that Crash on a distant planet. The story like isnt the best but it makes it back up with a amzing Art Design, great soundtrack and a Perfect multiplayer. The players are great and up to this point i havent found any bugs.The Friend sytem really makes it easy to just hop in a mission with your friends and take down to baddies.The monsters in this game are amazing and gives you a wide range of diffrent thingys to battle. One thing i love is your Sprite, the Battle Sprite is a small creature you gain what help fight of monsters, the Sprites all have diffrent powers and help in diffrent ways. You can not olny level up your sprite though, they are loads of cool loot you gain through out the game what really make you character strong, sneaky, fast or even magic. You can go to the auction house and sell or buy gear for great prices.While i am on about prices the game is 100% free to play, yes you can buy this thingy called Energy but there is ways of using in game cash to buy i to so you will never need to fork cash out. The one downfall out the game is that at nearly every point in this game you will be reading a peice of text, one thing i think they should add is voices so we dont need to click through pages upon pages of text.So over all i will rate this game 7/10 becuase there is a few things they need to fix but i really enjoy the missions within the game.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 19, 2014
												I still recommend this game, although I enjoyed the older versions much more.This game was once a unique masterpiece.  Everything just worked.  The prices, the balance, and especially the content.  Then the updates got worse.Buggy, hardly-tested updates were released, one after another, each one taking away from this game's uniqueness.  For example, just about every monster in the game has been "nerfed" to oblivion.  Fighting the monsters was once a challenge.  You could expect that construct to turn to face you when he attacked.  Instead, watch as he swings at the air and accomplishes nothing.  Nowadays, the only challenge is avoiding the hazards that the latency loves driving you into.The economy.  Originally, the energy prices were decent.  Then, they spiked up to ridiculous prices.  Once this game was brought to steam, the prices basically reset.  Then, the prices slowly began to increase past the once thought to be insane price.  Updates increased and decreased the prices, but one idea sure did it.  Flash sales on accessories which do nothing except make you look shinier spiked the prices past the ten thousand mark.  Now, the prices just go as they please, usually always too high for players just starting to accomplish anything.  While energy isn't as crucial as before, it's still worth mentioning the economy.And finally, the game's content itself.  What was once a beautiful, unique work of art became a shadow of it's former self.I'll start on the UI.  The old one was perfection.  It fitted the classic style of this game, and along with most of the glory in this game, was laid to rest.  In the year or so I've played after the GUI update, I can say I still never figured out most of it.  While the new UI wasn't popular, it still made it into the game, and remains to this day.As I mentioned earlier, each type of monster had the difficulty toned down on them.  This made the game itself a lot less challenging, taking some of the fun out of it.A lot of of updates were simply promotions at this point.  Costumes and accessories which had no effect on gameplay could be obtained through boxes the player had to buy.Not too long after this, the game basically changed entirely.  While the new UI stayed, the crafting system received a complete overhaul.  Energy wasn't the main component in actual gameplay anymore.  Elevators were free.  Crafting advanced gear was free.  The game was free.  While it was always "free-to-play", Spiral Knights had run mostly on energy before this, and new players wouldn't be able to accomplish much at the very start.  Now, new players could progress.  This was a step in the right direction.Some new updates showed up, including some eerie content, and a festive Holiday update.  An update geared toward gunners is also still in the works.Despite all of the bad things I have said, this game isn't bad.  It's just terrible compared to the old days, and I'll always try to remember Spiral Knights for how it once was.  A treasure.  A unique land of fun.A legend.

content:
Posted: January 30, 2016
												First, I'd like to say that I've played 507 hours of this game[tinypic.com] in the downloadable client, so please don't take my 1.4 hours on record too seriously.The PVE gets boring and repetitive after a while, given that there are very few missions are worth doing save for advancing in the questline. However, it does last for some time(around a hundred hours) and for that bit is is a delightful experience. If that's all you're going to do, I suggest you play another game.The best part of this game is... dressup. I'm not going to lie. Development on this game for the most part has been centered on creating more and more costumes for players to use, and other things like PVE and general gameplay has been left behind. With that in mind, costumes are now cooler and better looking than ever, and surpass other aspects of this game. This opens up many opportunities for players. Here are some examples of costumes I've been using:1[i.imgsafe.org] 2[i.imgsafe.org]Another great part of this game is the social aspect. Players in this game are often kind, helpful, and interesting individuals. If you get in a large guild of any kind, you could treat this as a medium for general chatting and socializing.Maybe you're wondering what I did in those 400 hours that I didn't spend doing PVE. Well, I was trading. Trading is a fun experience, especially reselling. All of my equipment and costumes came from buying items(specifically 5* sprite food) at half of what it's worth and selling it at market price. I've spent days on end simply just zone chatting various different offers, and while eventually I got bored with it- it was wonderful while it lasted.All in all, I suggest you play this game. Don't let the negative reviews get to you, there is very little harm in trying out a free to play game.

content:
Posted: May 10, 2014
												A delightful, free-to-play game that plays like a combination of Zelda mechanics and Gauntlet gameplay, settings allow for equal enjoyability of single player and multiplayer, and the game never really forces or heckles you for cash. It's very stylish and responsive, with a newly designed mission *every day*, alongside a mechanics-enforcing core Story Mode, and a randomizable Arcade Mode with shifting themes, a variety of settings that give a variety of objective strategies, and of course, is all about stylish customization. Masterfully brilliant, and accessible from casuals to masocore players (Elite difficulty is made with 4 competent players in mind, so playing through that with one? Doable, but good luck!)Some resources may seem obscured by currency barriers, but enough 'crowns' (the coins you collect in the level) can add up to enough, or you can usually get the resources themselves by playing Story Mode chapters. Very infectious soundtrack, as well. Just a pure delight, assuming you have a good broadband connection.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 19, 2014
												I still recommend this game, although I enjoyed the older versions much more.This game was once a unique masterpiece.  Everything just worked.  The prices, the balance, and especially the content.  Then the updates got worse.Buggy, hardly-tested updates were released, one after another, each one taking away from this game's uniqueness.  For example, just about every monster in the game has been "nerfed" to oblivion.  Fighting the monsters was once a challenge.  You could expect that construct to turn to face you when he attacked.  Instead, watch as he swings at the air and accomplishes nothing.  Nowadays, the only challenge is avoiding the hazards that the latency loves driving you into.The economy.  Originally, the energy prices were decent.  Then, they spiked up to ridiculous prices.  Once this game was brought to steam, the prices basically reset.  Then, the prices slowly began to increase past the once thought to be insane price.  Updates increased and decreased the prices, but one idea sure did it.  Flash sales on accessories which do nothing except make you look shinier spiked the prices past the ten thousand mark.  Now, the prices just go as they please, usually always too high for players just starting to accomplish anything.  While energy isn't as crucial as before, it's still worth mentioning the economy.And finally, the game's content itself.  What was once a beautiful, unique work of art became a shadow of it's former self.I'll start on the UI.  The old one was perfection.  It fitted the classic style of this game, and along with most of the glory in this game, was laid to rest.  In the year or so I've played after the GUI update, I can say I still never figured out most of it.  While the new UI wasn't popular, it still made it into the game, and remains to this day.As I mentioned earlier, each type of monster had the difficulty toned down on them.  This made the game itself a lot less challenging, taking some of the fun out of it.A lot of of updates were simply promotions at this point.  Costumes and accessories which had no effect on gameplay could be obtained through boxes the player had to buy.Not too long after this, the game basically changed entirely.  While the new UI stayed, the crafting system received a complete overhaul.  Energy wasn't the main component in actual gameplay anymore.  Elevators were free.  Crafting advanced gear was free.  The game was free.  While it was always "free-to-play", Spiral Knights had run mostly on energy before this, and new players wouldn't be able to accomplish much at the very start.  Now, new players could progress.  This was a step in the right direction.Some new updates showed up, including some eerie content, and a festive Holiday update.  An update geared toward gunners is also still in the works.Despite all of the bad things I have said, this game isn't bad.  It's just terrible compared to the old days, and I'll always try to remember Spiral Knights for how it once was.  A treasure.  A unique land of fun.A legend.

content:
Posted: December 30, 2015
												If you have friends who are willing to play this game with you, then ignore this review and play the game.Although I only have very few hours on this game, be assured I had much more before I had steam and I downloaded this game from the internet. It's golden time was in the spring of 2013 when people really enjoyed spending all their mist energy (ancient version of crystal energy which charged throughout the day/night and was used for the elevators in the levels) and then going to haven to trade all their loot. In the summer of 2013 a big update came along which changed the UI and the supply depot (kozma used to sell cobalt-azure stuff instead of everything, very useful) and also introduced the mission system and the forge system. It also made trips to the clockworks free so mist energy was removed from the game. Although many players liked this, most didn't because it meant the game had lost it bare-bones feel by replacing it with missions and CE purchases and grinding which ruined the game. Before this massive update, when starting the game you had to customize your character, do the basic tutorial and cross the chasm into haven, from there you were left to explore the rest of the game with the help of those who already knew. After the update, missions led to the trashy lore with razwog and other crappy characters as opposed to finding out yourself. The missions meant that visiting the clockworks was child's play and took away the dark souls difficulty to getting recon modules and finding out about what the game was about. Before the update, to buy exclusive and special items, you had to either find them yourself from boss tokens or trade at the AH for them, afterwards you could buy them more expensively from the supply depot with used to be home to the azure tree which was only available from kozma and the AH. AH prices boomed and became unpopular due to the supply depot, people could find and beat bosses by using the missions which eventually led to the tier system being demolished (the tier system was a system in the clockworks which prevented new players from farming too much and meant that it was at least possible for the tier 3 player to be able to spend his mist energy on the levels they want to farm). The forge system meant players had to constantly grind and forage the clockworks for pointless rocks which level up items, which led to players getting fed up and buying it for real money as opposed to just looting the clockworks the hard way and levelling up your items as you went along, which meant it was easier to build and buy new items. Lockdown and Bomber was introduced which was pretty pointless except for guildwars and general showing off items, after the clockworks were deemed unusable, people turned to lockdown and bomber which now is 99.99% of the game. The devs gave up after half the community left by the end of the year. No new items were introduced anymore, just the same old specials being rerun after that. Also, pointless costumes being introduced. The lore was ruined, the bare-bones feel was taken away, people didn't need or want to trade anymore and PVP was the only way out. People who couldn't keep up or wouldn't keep up decided to leave along with the devs who bailed on the game with the money they made. By mid 2014 there were only 10% of what used to be the amount of people playing. International servers were empty and 'active' guilds only had 2-3 players. The game as of the end of 2015 is now dead, there are only around 200 people playing at midday which is the peak of people online at the same time. For anyone new or old who doesn't have any friends willing to play SK along with them, leave this game alone, the devs killed it.

Posted: February 21
												A while back I used to play it a lot. This was way before I even had a Steam account. Or maybe I just didn't play it on here. But after a few years, or maybe more, the game has lost what it used to be. Most negative reviews can explain it in detail, but what I am saying here is that many players who played the game before things like missions and pets knew how fun and exciting it actually used to be, as it wasn't about grinding or paying to get items, instead it was more about teamwork and parties going as deep into the dungeon as they could before dying or running out of energy.Sadly the game lost what it used to be, though it's music and art remains to be some of the best I ever had seen in games. If it ever were to be revived in another game, hopefully they would be able to get the original developer working on it again, as if I recall he is what made the whole game feel magical.

content:
Posted: November 7, 2014
												The game is fun and harmless until you get to about 3-4 star equipment then it becomes a massive grind, and if you have no one to do your rank missions with you it is very hard to solo them. The best gear you can get is only obtainable by buying the equivalent of 5 dollars worth of Energy to get a key which unlocks the Shadow Lairs. To level your equipment you have to gain a ridiculous amount of heat (exp) to level them and when you cap it the items heat you can't move to the next level of the equipment unless you get lucky with the RNG Fire system. Fire can be found by playing the game or you can buy 50 fire for real money... You basically pay to level up late game, it's ridiculous. (Unless of course you want to grind the same levels again and again.)Overall:It's a fun game to an extent, but it loses it's charm after countless grinds through arcade mode just to get to a boss and gain tokens or hope you get the correct material drops.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 7, 2015
												Spiral Knights is a good game if you like this style of game. It has a wide variety of levels, enemies and challenge levels. It is great to play with friends or just other people who are online. There are some great features including tiered weaponry and armour, vendors to buy and sell your stuff for a set price, an auction house where players can sell and buy each others' stuff, guild groups and more. I really like how monsters and weapons are divided into groups so that each group of monster is weak to a certain group of weapons. You can play set 'rank missions', daily rotated 'prestige missions' or free-play style 'arcade missions'. Also has some good events and respective items that can sell for a lot outside of those events. However, do beware that this game can become quite addictive and a player often ends up 'grinding' for loot. this can take a lot of time and become rather frustrating and I think this is what turns most people off.Overall, I'd rate it a 7/10 because of these flaws mentioned that make you want to buy ingame currency.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: August 21, 2014
												Firstly, I have clocked hundreds of hours in this game (many before I linked it to Steam), so please do not think I dislike this game for no reason.The biggest problem with the game is the lack of content. Once you reach the end of the missions it all becomes very stale and pointless. There are very few updates that actually add proper content outside of time limited events in the game. (There has been no actual permanent content in 2014 so far). Every 2 weeks or so they add in time limited grindy lockboxes that you pay real money for a CHANCE to get a cosmetic item. Most of these lockboxes are reskins of existing content ingame, but rarely new models are used that could have been proper content in the game. It is extremely grindy to level your gear, and all you need to know is that it uses a punishing P2W system, with high paywalls to craft your weapons and armor. You can craft gear without paying money, but it takes an extremely long time. You can convert the normal ingame currency (Crowns) for the currency you pay real money for (Crystal Energy, or CE). The game has a real time fluctuating economy, and the rates of conversion change from time to time. They intentionally pump the game full of lockboxes with reskinned content to make the rates of conversion very high. The game has barely changed since its release in 2011. The only thing that I like about this game now is the art style and mechanics.The game has PVP, and I do not recommend it at all. It is broken and the PVP community is incredibly toxic. The devs also never respond to anything on the forums and cannot take constructive criticism without victimizing themselves.

content:
Posted: July 7, 2014
												This game is great. For an Ftp, it has lots of depth and you can get tons of gameplay hours out of it. If you ever get bored playing other games, it's really easy to get back into it which is a very noteable quality to the game. There are so many different types of weapons and armors to suit the way you like to play, and you can switch out different weapon types if you're just getting bored of your usual style.    I also love the soundtrack, especially the boss theme. The only big negative thing I have to say about the game is that at times it can be a little annoying to get money, and you may end up doing the same mission over and over just to get enough.  There are even prestige missions that change daily, as well as arcade missions where you won't need to stop the fun until you reach the core. (Which could take a very long time!) There are also 3 DLC quests that come in a bundle available on the steam store that give access to unique and otherwise unobtainable gear items. Go download SK, and get your free hours of fun!

content:
Posted: August 5, 2014
												I don't even care about the story. Like others have mentioned, I see this as an arcade game through and through. In my opinion, the biggest replay value comes from the desire to upgrade your equipment but also expand your arsenal. And that's no easy task. In order to upgrade or forge equipment you need certain materials that could take days to find. Literal days. But there's a lot of satisfaction seeing how your 5 star equipment crushes enemies that once crushed you. And just generally playing the game is fun. I always feel it's a battle of tenacity, trying to see how long you can really survive. It's kind of fun being the last one alive in your party, desperately battling through enemies to avoid letting your friends down. And if you aren't the type to be motivated by upgrades, there's a lot of cosmetic stuff too you can buy with in-game currency. If you're willing to grind enough. I'd definitely recommend at least trying the game. It's free, I logged 100 hours easily, and it's a lot of fun.

												I had an inventory tab for this game for quite a few years with seven items. It didn't bother me much until I hit the inventory limit lately and I couldn't find a way to get rid of it since the items weren't even tradable. Solution:1. Install the game again (I know, ew.)2. Remove all the knights you have (Right there after you download the updates. Yes, updates after a fresh install.)3. Remove the game from your account with the new feature (Support -> Remove product, etc.)The inventory tab disappeared along with the items.The review is negative because I remember the game as boring, tedious and not much of a challenge. In addition it left me with a burden of some untradable items that I couldn't get rid of without installing it again.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 27, 2016
												This game used to be amazing back in the day. Now? not so much. Here's why:The main reason is the incredibly laggy servers. Even in the EU server, the connections seem poor. Enemies and players alike will experience tons of rollback which will lead to some very cheap deaths from retracting spikes and the like. The lag makes swords basically useless as the long ending frames of the swing combos, coupled with the lag of the servers, will make you not shield in time and take a hit (possibly from several enemies at once), and trust me, many a Sparks of Life were lost because of this. Essentially this ends up forcing you to either only use the first swing of your sword's combo, which will neuter your damage output, or completely give up your sword altogether and just use the gun to deal damage while kiting enemies, which I have found to be the best strategy.The pets are cool and all, but mostly useless for the first few levels, and since I was already almost mid-game when they were added, I really don't use mine at all.At least they got rid of the Candy Crush-esque energy elevator system, I guess. Even though sometimes I find myself wishing I could go back to those days.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 7, 2015
												Oh Three Rings, where shall I begin with this game of yours...When I first played it, I enjoyed it immensely. I spent money on this game frequently, not because I wanted a certain item, but because I wanted them to develop it more, I wanted to help towards better graphics, new weapons and armour. I believed they could make this popular if they tried, but they didn't.Three Rings have fell victim to one of a game developer's top predators: laziness and greed. For the past year the only 'updates' are just recolours of existing items. There are no new, fresh levels or missions, no new weapons, no new armour, just a different colour of the item you already have. As you play through the game you'll first notice how repetitive the level designs are and eventually you get to the Vanguard rank (which isn't too hard to do if you're dedicated like I was) and you realize there's pretty much nothing for you to do anymore. No exclusive levels or missions for Vanguards, no nothing, the game sort of says "Yeah, good job completing me. I guess you can go now". You're stuck with prestige missions which, like everything else, are just repeated. Due to this and the lack of any sort of significant update (if you can even call them updates at this point), most players have quit. Three Rings have have caught on to this fact, they want to put as little effort into updates in an attempt to wring out any extra cash you have, or at least that's my only logical explaination.As it stands today, I'm severely dissapointed.

content:
Posted: June 19, 2014
												The word gay arrived in English during the 12th century from Old French gai, most likely deriving ultimately from a Germanic source.[1] For most of its life in English, the word's primary meaning was "joyful", "carefree", "bright and showy", and the word was very commonly used with this meaning in speech and literature. For example, the optimistic 1890s are still often referred to as the Gay Nineties. The title of the 1938 French ballet Gaîté Parisienne ("Parisian Gaiety"), which became the 1941 Warner Brothers movie, The Gay Parisian,[7] also illustrates this connotation. It was apparently not until the 20th century that the word began to be used to mean specifically "homosexual", although it had earlier acquired sexual connotations.[1]The derived abstract noun gaiety remains largely free of sexual connotations, and has, in the past, been used in the names of places of entertainment; for example W.B. Yeats heard Oscar Wilde lecture at the Gaiety Theatre in Dublin.[8]SexualizationUsage statistics from English books, according to Google Ngram Viewer.The word may have started to acquire associations of immorality as early as the 14th century, and had certainly acquired them by the 17th.[1] By the late 17th century it had acquired the specific meaning of "addicted to pleasures and dissipations",[9] an extension of its primary meaning of "carefree" implying "uninhibited by moral constraints." A gay woman was a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥, a gay man a womanizer and a gay house a brothel.[1]The use of gay to mean "homosexual" was in origin merely an extension of the word's sexualised connotation of "carefree and uninhibited", which implied a willingness to disregard conventional or respectable sexual mores. Such usage is documented as early as the 1920s, and there is evidence for it before the 20th century,[1] although it was initially more commonly used to imply heterosexually unconstrained lifestyles, as in the once-common phrase "gay Lothario",[10] or in the title of the book and film The Gay Falcon (1941), which concerns a womanizing detective whose first name is "Gay." Similarly, Gilbert and MacDermott's music hall song of the 1880s, "Charlie Dilke Upset the Milk" – "Master Dilke upset the milk/When taking it home to Chelsea;/ The papers say that Charlie's gay/Rather a wilful wag!" – referred to Sir Charles Dilke's alleged heterosexual impropriety.[11] Well into the mid 20th century a middle-aged bachelor could be described as "gay", indicating that he was unattached and therefore free, without any implication of homosexuality. This usage could apply to women too. The British comic strip Jane was first published in the 1930s and described the adventures of Jane Gay. Far from implying homosexuality, it referred to her free-wheeling lifestyle with plenty of boyfriends (while also punning on Lady Jane Grey).A passage from Gertrude Stein's Miss Furr & Miss Skeene (1922) is possibly the first traceable published use of the word to refer to a homosexual relationship. According to Linda Wagner-Martin (Favored Strangers: Gertrude Stein and her Family (1995)) the portrait, "featured the sly repetition of the word gay, used with sexual intent for one of the first times in linguistic history," and Edmund Wilson (1951, quoted by James Mellow in Charmed Circle (1974)) agreed.[12] For example:They were ...gay, they learned little things that are things in being gay, ... they were quite regularly gay.—Gertrude Stein, 1922Through the mid 20th century, the term "gay" commonly referred to "carefree", as illustrated in the Astaire and Rogers film The Gay Divorcee. (See detailed discussion in article.)Bringing Up Baby (1938) was the first film to use the word gay in apparent reference to homosexuality. In a scene in which the Cary Grant character's clothes have been sent to the cleaners, he is forced to wear a woman’s feather-trimmed robe. When another character asks about his robe, he responds, "Because I just went gay all of a sudden!" Since this was a mainstream film at a time when the use of the word to refer to homosexuality would still be unfamiliar to most film-goers, the line can also be interpreted to mean "I just decided to do something frivolous."[13]The word continued to be used with the dominant meaning of "carefree", as evidenced by the title of The Gay Divorcee (1934), a musical film about a heterosexual couple.Shift to homosexualBy the mid-20th century, gay was well established in reference to hedonistic and uninhibited lifestyles[9] and its antonym straight, which had long had connotations of seriousness, respectability, and conventionality, had now acquired specific connotations of heterosexuality.[14] In the case of gay, other connotations of frivolousness and showiness in dress ("gay apparel") led to association with camp and effeminacy. This association no doubt helped the gradual narrowing in scope of the term towards its current dominant meaning, which was at first confined to subcultures. Gay was the preferred term since other terms, such as queer, were felt to be derogatory.[15] Homosexual is perceived as excessively clinical,[16][17][18] since the sexual orientation now commonly referred to as "homosexuality" was at that time a mental illness diagnosis in the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders (DSM).In mid-20th century Britain, where male homosexuality was illegal until the Sexual Offences Act 1967, to openly identify someone as homosexual was considered very offensive and an accusation of serious criminal activity. Additionally, none of the words describing any aspect of homosexuality were considered suitable for polite society. Consequently, a number of euphemisms were used to hint at suspected homosexuality. Examples include "sporty" girls and "artistic" boys,[19] all with the stress deliberately on the otherwise completely innocent adjective.The sixties marked the transition in the predominant meaning of the word gay from that of "carefree" to the current "homosexual".In the British comedy-drama film Light Up The Sky! (1960) directed by Lewis Gilbert about the antics of a British Army searchlight squad during World War II, there is a scene in the mess hut where the character played by Benny Hill proposes an after dinner toast. He begins, "I'd lke to propose..." at which point a fellow diner, played by Sidney Tafler, interjects "Who to?", suggesting a proposal of marriage. The Benny Hill character responds, "Not to you for start, you ain't my type". He then adds in mock doubt, "Oh, I don't know, you're rather gay on the quiet."By 1963, a new sense of the word gay was known well enough to be used by Albert Ellis in his book The Intelligent Woman's Guide to Man-Hunting. Similarly, Hubert Selby, Jr. in his 1964 novel Last Exit to Brooklyn, could write that a character "took pride in being a homosexual by feeling intellectually and esthetically superior to those (especially women) who weren't gay..."[20] Later examples of the original meaning of the word being used in popular culture include the theme song to the 1960–1966 animated TV series The Flintstones, whereby viewers are assured that they will "have a gay old time." Similarly, the 1966 Herman's Hermits song "No Milk Today", which became a Top 10 hit in the UK and a Top 40 hit in the U.S. and included the lyric "No milk today, it was not always so / The company was gay, we'd turn night into day."[21] In June 1967, the headline of the review of the Beatles' Sgt. Pepper's Lonely Hearts Club Band album in the British daily newspaper The Times stated, "The Beatles revive hopes of progress in pop music with their gay new LP".[22] Yet in the same year, The Kinks recorded "David Watts".[23] Ostensibly about schoolboy envy, the song also operated as an in-joke, as related in Jon Savage's "The Kinks: The Official Biography", because the song took its name from a homosexual promoter they'd encountered who'd had romantic designs on songwriter

Posted: November 7, 2014
												The game is fun and harmless until you get to about 3-4 star equipment then it becomes a massive grind, and if you have no one to do your rank missions with you it is very hard to solo them. The best gear you can get is only obtainable by buying the equivalent of 5 dollars worth of Energy to get a key which unlocks the Shadow Lairs. To level your equipment you have to gain a ridiculous amount of heat (exp) to level them and when you cap it the items heat you can't move to the next level of the equipment unless you get lucky with the RNG Fire system. Fire can be found by playing the game or you can buy 50 fire for real money... You basically pay to level up late game, it's ridiculous. (Unless of course you want to grind the same levels again and again.)Overall:It's a fun game to an extent, but it loses it's charm after countless grinds through arcade mode just to get to a boss and gain tokens or hope you get the correct material drops.

content:
Posted: July 7, 2015
												Spiral Knights is a good game if you like this style of game. It has a wide variety of levels, enemies and challenge levels. It is great to play with friends or just other people who are online. There are some great features including tiered weaponry and armour, vendors to buy and sell your stuff for a set price, an auction house where players can sell and buy each others' stuff, guild groups and more. I really like how monsters and weapons are divided into groups so that each group of monster is weak to a certain group of weapons. You can play set 'rank missions', daily rotated 'prestige missions' or free-play style 'arcade missions'. Also has some good events and respective items that can sell for a lot outside of those events. However, do beware that this game can become quite addictive and a player often ends up 'grinding' for loot. this can take a lot of time and become rather frustrating and I think this is what turns most people off.Overall, I'd rate it a 7/10 because of these flaws mentioned that make you want to buy ingame currency.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: August 21, 2014
												Firstly, I have clocked hundreds of hours in this game (many before I linked it to Steam), so please do not think I dislike this game for no reason.The biggest problem with the game is the lack of content. Once you reach the end of the missions it all becomes very stale and pointless. There are very few updates that actually add proper content outside of time limited events in the game. (There has been no actual permanent content in 2014 so far). Every 2 weeks or so they add in time limited grindy lockboxes that you pay real money for a CHANCE to get a cosmetic item. Most of these lockboxes are reskins of existing content ingame, but rarely new models are used that could have been proper content in the game. It is extremely grindy to level your gear, and all you need to know is that it uses a punishing P2W system, with high paywalls to craft your weapons and armor. You can craft gear without paying money, but it takes an extremely long time. You can convert the normal ingame currency (Crowns) for the currency you pay real money for (Crystal Energy, or CE). The game has a real time fluctuating economy, and the rates of conversion change from time to time. They intentionally pump the game full of lockboxes with reskinned content to make the rates of conversion very high. The game has barely changed since its release in 2011. The only thing that I like about this game now is the art style and mechanics.The game has PVP, and I do not recommend it at all. It is broken and the PVP community is incredibly toxic. The devs also never respond to anything on the forums and cannot take constructive criticism without victimizing themselves.

content:
Posted: August 3, 2015
												When you look at the amount of hours I've spent on this game you might question why I don't recommend the game. Well, there is a plethora of reasons.1)PvE is absolute garbage in this game. There is pretty much no challenging content. Sure a mission might get you once or twice but once you know what's going on it's easy peasy from there. This hinders replayability value substantially. It wouldn't be a problem if the game had massive amounts of levels all of which payed out decently to be worth your time but no, it has one mission which must be done for money otherwise you're wasting your time. 2)Serious balance issues. Many weapons/armours are rubbish and completely avoided most of the time. Now you might be thinking that every mmo has tons of weapons which are rubbish and the good weapons are the rares which are difficult to obtain. Well you'd be thinking of a normal mmo. In this game there is no such thing as rarity as far as a weapon goes. Each weapon is obtained in the same way as another and it is not based on random drops, it is based on you crafting them. No luck involved either(unless you're aiming for variants, I'll touch on those later). So, why is the majority of the weapons/armours useless ? Cause the developers can't be arsed to fix them.3)Developer. The developer of this game is one of the absolute worst. They don't even put out updates or even reach out the community. All they do is put promos into the game(essentially cosmetic items you need to pay for) every 2 weeks which half the time actually end up breaking some of the game.4)This game has quite a lot of pay to win elements. It isn't really a big issue in PvP because it is largely based on skill there(and thank god) but there is still pay to win elements meaning you can theoretically buy gear which makes you quite a bit better than your enemy(can take more hits to kill you, faster attack speed etc) which should not be in a pvp game!5)Servers. This game has awful servers and that's coming from a guy who has single digit ping on the EU server and only double digit ping on the USA server. I'm not sure if it's the actual servers or the net code that the game has but either way, the game has some serious connectivity problems. I obviously don't expierence those(most of the time) but many, many others do. In fact this game is usually a battle of the ping rather than a real fight.6)Horrid optimisation. Based on Java, nuff said. There's many more reasons that this game just isn't worth your time while there are other games out there however if you do decide to play the game there is only a handful of things that this game is worth playing for.1)PvP. Even though it has many issues it is still a pretty fun PvP expierence. 2)Community. One of the best communities ever. Made so many friends in the game.3)Kind of gimmicky mechanics which can be interesting for a short while. 4)Actually good combat system unlike every mmo.---Reviewed by the best Spiral Knights player 2014-2015, rip Tempas.(just kidding, best one is Maiso, go ask him for tips on how to play lockdown!)

content:
Posted: January 25, 2015
												This game started very good and ended up getting bad as i progressed in the game. I have good experiences but also a few bad ones which eventually made me quit spiral knights.I started playing together with a friend just to try it out but as we progressed i eventually came to the conclusion that it was a fun game so i got into it. During my plays i kept hitting several walls though. My first problem was the repetitive level design which started to look the same the more i played it. I dismissed that problem eventually in favor of the story line but my biggest problem was levelling the armor and weapons, the higher tier i get the harder it becomes to get the crafting materials thus more tempting it gets to purchase what items you need from the store with real money. You can't progress the storyline unless you level up your armor at least 5 times at set points in the story line.This means you either have to grind insane amounts of levels and trade a lot of it with others in order to get the amounts of ingame currency or do it the easy attractive way and convert real currency such as dollars pounds or euros at the ingame store to energy used to buy weapons and armor at prices which eventually equals the price of a full new retail price of a game if not more. The transaction options didn't sit very well with me either, You can either pay by credit card which is pretty normal here on steam for people aged 18 and over but here's the thing. You can pay by text message as well. Just give the ingame store your cellphone number and they send you a message, You agree and they make money from the message you send. What do all the kids walk around with these days? They all have cellphones that the parents gave them and that text message transaction option will make it very tempting for underage kids to make the mistake by going overboard with their cellhpone without the parent's consult. I'm not too fond of this kind of practises. I had much fun with this game and that won't be forgotten but the more i played the more downhill it went. I abandoned it when i reached the 4 star armor cap and i'm fine with it. The only thing i will miss is the helpful community that this game has. It saved my bacon more than once.Still, don't let all this discourage you from trying it out. This game is free to play and you can download this game for yourself whenever you like and form an opinion based on your own experiences. That is something i can recommend.I hope my info has been helpful to you.All the best!(s.i.e)

content:
Posted: January 25, 2015
												This game started very good and ended up getting bad as i progressed in the game. I have good experiences but also a few bad ones which eventually made me quit spiral knights.I started playing together with a friend just to try it out but as we progressed i eventually came to the conclusion that it was a fun game so i got into it. During my plays i kept hitting several walls though. My first problem was the repetitive level design which started to look the same the more i played it. I dismissed that problem eventually in favor of the story line but my biggest problem was levelling the armor and weapons, the higher tier i get the harder it becomes to get the crafting materials thus more tempting it gets to purchase what items you need from the store with real money. You can't progress the storyline unless you level up your armor at least 5 times at set points in the story line.This means you either have to grind insane amounts of levels and trade a lot of it with others in order to get the amounts of ingame currency or do it the easy attractive way and convert real currency such as dollars pounds or euros at the ingame store to energy used to buy weapons and armor at prices which eventually equals the price of a full new retail price of a game if not more. The transaction options didn't sit very well with me either, You can either pay by credit card which is pretty normal here on steam for people aged 18 and over but here's the thing. You can pay by text message as well. Just give the ingame store your cellphone number and they send you a message, You agree and they make money from the message you send. What do all the kids walk around with these days? They all have cellphones that the parents gave them and that text message transaction option will make it very tempting for underage kids to make the mistake by going overboard with their cellhpone without the parent's consult. I'm not too fond of this kind of practises. I had much fun with this game and that won't be forgotten but the more i played the more downhill it went. I abandoned it when i reached the 4 star armor cap and i'm fine with it. The only thing i will miss is the helpful community that this game has. It saved my bacon more than once.Still, don't let all this discourage you from trying it out. This game is free to play and you can download this game for yourself whenever you like and form an opinion based on your own experiences. That is something i can recommend.I hope my info has been helpful to you.All the best!(s.i.e)
